the family,
the self—
before birth, after death—
its use is inexhaustible.

If one would draw in the breath,
one must first exhale fully;
---

The one who would weaken it must first strengthen it;
The one who would discard it must first exalt it;
The one who would take from it must first give to it.
This is called **subtle luminosity**.

The yielding overcomes the rigid;
The weak overcomes the strong.

Fish cannot be lifted from the depths;
The state’s sharpest tools
should not be displayed to the people.

The one who would gather must first disperse;
The one who would weaken must first strengthen;
The one who would discard must first exalt;
The one who would take must first give.

Yin takes root in yang—
this is the inevitable order.

Those who grasp the logic of things
are said to possess **subtle luminosity**,
and thus know that yielding overcomes rigidity,
that weakness overcomes strength.

Fish cannot be separated from the depths—
just as the state’s sharpest tools,
once revealed, are like fish out of water.

When seals and decrees are issued,
when measures and scales are standardized,
these are the state’s useful tools.
Yet if one seeks to remedy flaws,
one must first allow corruption to flourish,
for failing to perceive the principle of **subtle luminosity**.

The **Dao** acts without action yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
all things would transform of their own accord.

When transformation stirs to action,
I shall govern it with the **nameless Primordial**.
The **nameless Primordial** also desires nothing.

Without desire, all things settle—
and the world will align itself.

To govern the world,
one must act without acting,
and yet nothing will remain ungoverned.

If lords and kings could uphold non-action,
all things would transform of their own accord.
But if transformation gives rise to restless desire,
I shall steady it with the **nameless Primordial**.
The **nameless Primordial** also desires nothing.

Without desire, all things grow still—
and the hearts of the people will align themselves.

The highest virtue does not cling to virtue,
and thus has virtue.
The lower virtue does not lose virtue,
and thus lacks virtue.

The highest virtue acts without acting,
the lower virtue acts with effort.
The highest benevolence acts without effort,
the highest righteousness acts with effort.
The highest propriety acts with effort,
yet when none respond,
it resorts to force and compulsion.

Thus, when the **Dao** is lost, virtue arises;
when virtue is lost, benevolence arises;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
when righteousness is lost, propriety arises.

For propriety is the thinning of sincerity and trust—
the beginning of chaos.

Premature wisdom is the flourish of the **Dao**,
the start of folly.

Thus, the superior person dwells in its depth,
not its shallowness;
in its reality,
not its flourish.
Hence, they discard the latter and embrace the former.

In the age of antiquity,
the highest virtue did not display its virtue,
and thus had virtue.
By the time of Fu Xi,
writing and marriage laws were established,
and virtue was made manifest—
thus becoming lower virtue.
Though it did not lose virtue,
it bore the traces of deliberate action,
and thus lacked virtue.

The highest virtue governs through non-action,
the lower virtue governs through deliberate teaching.
In the age of Yao and Shun,
the highest virtue loved people and benefited all,
acting as a benevolent ruler without effort.
In the age of the Three Kings,
the highest virtue established right and wrong,
distinguishing and acting—
thus with effort.
In the age of the Five Hegemons,
the highest virtue upheld ritual propriety in governance,
yet when ritual produced deceit and the people did not respond,
laws were enacted to make them fear punishment
and follow righteousness—
thus resorting to force and compulsion.

Thus, when the **Dao** is lost, virtue arises;
when virtue is lost, benevolence arises;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
when righteousness is lost, propriety arises.

For propriety is a method to save the world,
rooted in sincerity,
yet arising from the thinning of trust—
the origin of chaos.

Those who prematurely display wisdom
are but the flourish of the **Dao**,
not its substance,
and thus their adherence to its flourish
marks the beginning of folly among the people.

Hence, the superior person dwells in the depth of sincerity,
not its shallowness;
in the reality of the **Dao**,
not its flourish.
Thus, they discard the shallow and the flourish,
and embrace the deep and the real.

In ancient times, those who attained **Oneness**—
Heaven attained **Oneness** and became clear,
Earth attained **Oneness** and became tranquil,
The spirit attained **Oneness** and became responsive,
The valleys attained **Oneness** and became full,
All things attained **Oneness** and flourished,
And the lords and kings attained **Oneness**
to govern the world aright.

Yet if **Oneness** were lost—
Heaven, without **Oneness**, would fear fracturing,
Earth, without **Oneness**, would fear upheaval,
The spirit, without **Oneness**, would fear stagnation,
The valleys, without **Oneness**, would fear exhaustion,
All things, without **Oneness**, would fear extinction,
And lords and kings, without **Oneness**,
relying on their noble height,
would fear their position toppling.

Thus, nobility finds its foundation in humility,
and height finds its base in lowliness.
Hence, lords and kings call themselves "lonely, few, and unworthy"—
is this not their grounding in humility?
Is it not so?

Thus, true praise is without praise,
not like jade clinking or stone clattering.
**Oneness** is the mother of all things;
all things arise from **Oneness**.
Thus, to attain **Oneness** is to flourish,
to lose **Oneness** is to perish.

The **Laozi** speaks:
In ancient times, those who attained **Oneness**—
Heaven attained **Oneness** and became clear, covering all;
Earth attained **Oneness** and became tranquil, bearing all;
The human spirit attained **Oneness** and became responsive;
The valleys attained **Oneness** and became full;
All things attained **Oneness** and flourished;
And lords and kings, attaining **Oneness**,
governed the world aright.

Yet if **Oneness** were lost—
Heaven, without **Oneness**, would fear shattering,
Earth, without **Oneness**, would fear eruption,
The spirit, without **Oneness**, would fear fading,
The valleys, without **Oneness**, would fear depletion,
All things, without **Oneness**, would fear annihilation,
And lords and kings, without **Oneness**,
relying on their noble height,
losing reverence and humility,
would fear their position collapsing.

The noble, though in high estate, takes humility as root;
The exalted, though in lofty place, takes lowliness as foundation.
Thus do lords and kings—
Calling themselves "orphaned" when fatherless,
"widowed" when husbandless,
"without grain" when lacking sustenance—
All to descend to the lowly.
Is this not taking humility as root?
Or is it that, recognizing their noble height,
They thus invite the loss of **Oneness** through excessive praise?

Praise, when excessive, becomes blame;
A foundation without praise is better.
Thus, one does not seek the **tinkling** of jade-like praise,
Nor the **clattering** of stone-like censure.

The **Dao** moves through inversion;
The **weak** is the **Dao**’s operation.
All things arise from **Being**, yet **Being** arises from **Non-Being**.
He who gallops his mind outward
Finds nothing compared to turning it inward—
Thus, inversion is the **Dao**’s motion.

Motion, when returned to **Non-Being**, is called **weak**—
The **weak** is the **Dao**’s operation.

The world knows only that all things arise from **Being**,
Yet does not know that **Being** arises from **Non-Being**—
Thus, the **Non-Being** is the **Dao**’s operation.

The **Superior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Diligently practices it;
The **Middle Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Holds it as if it exists, as if it does not;
The **Inferior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Laughs at it—
And if he does not laugh, it is not the **Dao**.

The **Superior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Generates true faith and acts upon it—
Thus he is called **Superior**.
The **Middle Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Has no resolve within—
Holding it as if it exists, as if it does not—
Thus he is called **Middle**.
The **Inferior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Burdened by dust and deep in deeds,
Hearing its teaching, does not adhere to any single principle,
Yet, full of virtue and **power**,
He laughs at it.
The **Inferior Man** who does not laugh at the **Dao**
Must be clinging to strange, contrived, artificial methods—
This is not the **Dao**.

Thus it is said:
The **Dao**, though bright, seems dim;
The **Dao**, though smooth, seems rough;
Advancing the **Dao** seems like retreat;
**Virtue** at its height seems like a valley;
Great **whiteness** seems like shame;
Ample **virtue** seems insufficient;
Established **virtue** seems like theft;
True **simplicity** seems corrupt;
The greatest **rectitude** has no corners;
The greatest vessel is fashioned last;
The greatest music is without sound;
The greatest form is without shape—
The **Dao** is hidden, nameless.

Thus it is said:
The **Dao**, though bright, seems dim—
For enlightenment brings no gain, thus it seems obscured.
The **Dao**, though smooth, seems rough—
For the great **Way** is plain and unadorned, requiring no cultivation or proof.
Advancing the **Dao** seems like retreat—
For it requires no contrivance of the mind.
**Virtue** at its height seems like a valley—
For the heart, vast as emptiness, contains all things.
Great **whiteness** seems like shame—
For action without effort appears as disgrace.
Ample **virtue** seems insufficient—
For the virtuous, perfect in all deeds, yet appear lacking.
Established **virtue** seems like theft—
For its actions leave no trace.
True **simplicity** seems corrupt—
*Semü*—change. The mind, serene and still,
Adapts to all things without resistance—
Thus it seems transformed.
The greatest **rectitude** has no corners—
For brothels and taverns become **Dao**’s sanctuaries.
The greatest vessel is fashioned last—
For only through diligent, sincere practice does one attain fulfillment.
The greatest music is without sound—
For supreme harmony is self-evident.
The above eleven lines speak of the **Dao**’s hidden, nameless nature—
Thus, the **Dao** is formless, beyond name.

Only the **Dao**,
Lends itself to **sound** and **completion**.
The **Dao** generates **Oneness**,
**Oneness** generates **Twoness**,
**Twoness** generates **Threeness**,
**Threeness** generates all things.
All things bear **yin** while embracing **yang**,
And through **suong-qi** achieve harmony.
Only the **Dao**,
Lends itself to **borrowing**—*dài*—
**Yin** and **yang** generate and transform,
Yet ultimately return to the **Dao**.
From the **Dao** arises **One Qi**,
**One Qi** divides to form **Two Principles**,
**Two Principles** generate and transform,
With **One Qi** as master,
**One** merging with **Two**—
Thus **Threeness**.
**One Qi** dwells within **yin** and **yang**,
Hence called **suong-qi**.
Through **Threeness**, all things arise—
Thus all things bear **yin** on their backs
And embrace **yang** toward their fronts,
All relying on **suong-qi** for harmony—
Harmony is the root of life.

What men detest—
Orphaned, widowed, without grain—
Yet kings and lords adopt as titles,
Thus things may be lost to gain,
Or gained to lose.
What men teach,
I also teach as **right**.
The **strong and violent** do not meet a natural end—
I shall take this as my lesson.

Why do men detest orphaned, widowed, without grain,
Yet kings and lords adopt such titles?
The **Way** of governing the world
Takes humility as law—
Thus things may be lost to gain,
Or gained to lose,
And one knows that the humble receive benefit—
This was the teaching of the ancients.

The **Master** said:
I too teach humility as **right**—
Why?
For those who rely on strength and violence
Do not fulfill their governance and perish.

The **Master** said:
I shall teach the **Way** of humility,
Taking this as my father’s lesson.

The **softest** in the world
Overcomes the **hardest** in the world—
Nothing enters where there are no gaps.
Thus one knows the benefit of **Non-Action**.

The teaching of **Non-Speech**,
The benefit of **Non-Action**—
Few in the world attain it.

The **softest** in the world
Is the **heart without heart**—
Yet deeper still is **Xuan**.
If one can wield this **softness**,
It becomes the **hardest** in the world—
Unbreakable.

The ancient hymn says:
*"No head to see, no hands to hold—*
*When the world’s foundation is laid, it knows no decay."*
Through **Non-Being** as **Being**,
One enters the realm of **Non-Birth-and-Death**,
Eternally enduring, without interruption—
Thus one knows the benefit of **Non-Action**.
This is a teaching beyond words—
The **Master** sighed:
The benefit of **Non-Action**—
Few in the world attain it.

Which is more intimate—**name** or **body**?
Which is more abundant—**body** or **wealth**?
Which brings greater harm—**gain** or **loss**?
Thus, the more one loves excessively, the greater the expenditure;
The more one hoards, the greater the loss.
Knowing sufficiency brings no shame;
Knowing when to stop brings no peril—
Thus one may endure.

Which is more intimate—**high name** or **body**?
Which is more abundant—**body** or **wealth**?
Gain and loss arise from **name** and **profit—**
Which brings greater harm?

Thus, the one who loves **name** excessively will inevitably incur great costs when **name** grows vast;
The one who hoards **wealth** will surely suffer great loss when **wealth** becomes abundant.
To dwell in **name** yet know sufficiency brings no shame,
To dwell in **wealth** yet know when to stop brings no peril—
Thus one may endure.

The great completion seems incomplete,
Yet its use is never exhausted.
The great fullness seems empty,
Yet its use is never depleted.
The great uprightness seems crooked,
The great cleverness seems clumsy,
The great eloquence seems tongue-tied.

**Yang** overcomes **cold** (by its vigor),
**Yin** overcomes **heat** (by its stillness),
**Qingjing** (purity and tranquility) is the **Dao** of the world.

Great completion is like inversion—
Thus it seems as if it were not fully realized,
Yet its use is never exhausted.
**Defeat** is like great fullness—
Thus it seems as if it were empty,
Yet its use is never depleted.

Great uprightness does not assert itself—
Thus it seems like crookedness;
Great cleverness conceals its wisdom—
Thus it seems like clumsiness;
Great eloquence does not speak—
Thus it seems like tongue-tiedness.

Hence, incompleteness can overcome completion,
emptiness can overcome fullness,
crookedness can overcome uprightness.
Clumsiness overcomes cleverness,
tongue-tiedness overcomes eloquence—
Just as **Yang** overcomes **cold** (when active),
**Yin** overcomes **heat** (when still).
This is like medicine countering illness,
and only **purity, tranquility, and Non-Action** can void all **realms** and achieve absolute cure—
Thus it is the **Dao** of the world.

When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
warhorses are turned back to till the fields;
When the **Dao** is absent from the world,
warhorses breed in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than **desire** for what is **obtainable**,
No calamity is greater than **greed** for what is **unknowable**,
No fault is greater than **covetousness** for what is **acquired**.

Hence, one who truly knows sufficiency is always sufficient.
The ancient **army** was the **peasantry**,
And the **peasantry** was the **army**—
When there was conflict, they fought;
When there was peace, they cultivated.
When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
the people each settle into their occupations,
and warhorses are turned back to till the fields.
Soldiers use their **excrement** to fertilize the fields,
and they attend to agricultural matters.

When the **Dao** is absent from the world,
warhorses multiply in the suburbs—
Thirty **li** from the royal **city** is the near suburb,
Sixty **li** from the royal **city** is the far suburb.
The cause of the absence of the **Dao** is this:

No crime is greater than indulging the **heart** in **desire** for what is **obtainable**,
No calamity is greater than gluttony of the **heart** in **unknowing** sufficiency,
No fault is greater than fixating the **heart** on **covetousness** for what is **acquired**.

Indeed, crimes, calamities, and faults all arise from **desire**.
If the **heart** is without **desire**,
Then one can know sufficiency—
Its sufficiency is always sufficient,
Whatever it encounters.
Calamities and faults are thus removed—
What crimes can there be?

Without stepping outside the door,
One knows the world;
Without peering through the window,
One sees the **Dao** of Heaven.

The more one strays far from it, the less one knows of it.
Hence, the Sage does not act yet knows,
Does not see yet names,
Does not do yet accomplishes.

The **Dao** uniformly permeates all things,
Yet its knowing lies within oneself.
To seek the **Dao**, one need not step outside the door—
Only reflect upon the mind,
For its essence is one with all things,
Thus one knows all things under Heaven.

If one can further abandon the traces of reflection,
With the mind free from attachments,
Then one need not peer through the window—
Even without outward gaze,
One sees the **Dao** of Heaven.

But if one seeks the **Dao** through calculations,
Through **yin-yang** [阴阳],
Through human affairs,
The farther one strays,
The less one knows.

Hence, the Sage does not act yet knows the nature of all things,
Does not see yet names what Heaven creates,
And remains without doing yet accomplishes all.

In learning, one gains incrementally;
In the **Dao**, one diminishes daily.
Diminish again and again,
Until one reaches **wuwei** [无为],
**Wuwei** yet accomplishes all.

Therefore, those who take all under Heaven,
Always act with **wuwei** [无事],
Yet when they must act,
Their actions are insufficient to take all under Heaven.

For those who learn, daily they strive for increase—
For those who seek the **Dao**, daily they diminish all entanglements.

Now, those who seek learning through increase have two afflictions:
The first is reading, reciting, and copying,
Holding onto many teachings—
This is called **fixation on things** [名着事].

The second is probing into textual meanings,
Exhaustively examining words and logic—
This is called **fixation on principles** [名着理].

These are all cases where the mind has attachments,
Thus they must be diminished.

Those who seek the **Dao** through diminishing also have two afflictions:
The first is severing delusive thoughts,
Seeking stillness outside the mind—
This is called **grasping at nothingness** [名执无].

The second is rejecting all dusty entanglements,
Exclusively guarding the mind—
This is called **grasping at somethingness** [名执有].

These are all cases where the mind clings,
Thus they must be diminished again.

Diminish the mind of learning and the mind of seeking the **Dao**,
Abandon attachments and clinging,
Until one reaches the **Dao** of **wuwei** [无为之道].
**Wuwei** is acting without a fixed mind.
Not without a mind—
It means the mind is devoid of all thoughts,
Called **wuxin** [无心].

Acting without a mind,
Naturally the senses are empty,
Listening and observing freely,
Spontaneously removing poverty and wealth,
Liking and disliking,
The toil of **yunshui** [运水], **banchaishu** [般柴役],
Moving through the world without encumbrance,
Thus **wuwei** yet accomplishes all things.

Hence, those who take and govern all under Heaven with the **Dao**,
Always act with **wuwei** [无事],
Yet when they must act,
Their actions are insufficient to take and govern all under Heaven.

The Sage has no fixed mind,
Taking the hearts of the people as their own.
The virtuous, I treat as virtuous—
The not virtuous, I also treat as virtuous,
Thus **virtue** is accomplished.
The trustworthy, I trust—
The untrustworthy, I also trust,
Thus **virtue** is trustworthy.

The Sage’s presence in all under Heaven,
Is like the sound of **"hunxin"** [浑心],
For the people are all focused on their ears and eyes,
While the Sage nurtures them like children.

The Sage acts with **wuwei** [无为], **wuwei** [无为],
Without fixed intentions in their actions,
Yet responds to affairs with the people’s hearts—
As the *Jiyu* [《击辞》] says:
*"Silent and unmoving, yet responsive—*
*Thus they naturally harmonize with all under Heaven."*

Their **virtue** is revealed through the affairs they encounter.
The virtuous, I treat as virtuous—
If there are the not virtuous,
The Sage does not distinguish,
Yet I also treat them as virtuous,
Thus **virtue** transforms the people into goodness.

The trustworthy, I trust—
If there are the untrustworthy,
The Sage does not distinguish,
Yet I also trust them,
Thus **virtue** transforms the people into trustworthiness.

Therefore, the Sage’s presence in all under Heaven:
If they doubt not the things,
Then all under Heaven’s things become trustworthy;
If they favor not the things,
Then all under Heaven’s things become public;
If they prize not the treasures,
Then all under Heaven will not gluttonously consume;
If they indulge not in excess,
Then all under Heaven will naturally follow frugality;
If they use what is true,
Then all under Heaven will not feign falsity;
If they exalt the humble,
Then all under Heaven will not contend.

Thus, the Sage’s **"hunxin"** [浑心] nurtures all under Heaven,
And the people all focus their **virtue** on their ears and eyes,
While the Sage remains in **wuwei** [无心] toward affairs,
Nurturing them like children.

Birth and death,
Those who live, thirteen in ten,
Those who die, thirteen in ten,
Even the people’s movement from life to death is thirteen in ten.
Why is this so?
Because of the **Dao**’s abundant nurturing of life.

The Master of Life Cultivation

It is said that those skilled in nurturing life
walk upon land yet meet no rhinoceros or tiger,
enter battle yet are unharmed by weapons.
The rhinoceros has no place to thrust its horn,
the tiger no place to strike with its claws,
the blade no place to lodge its edge.
Why is this so?
Because they dwell in no place of death.

Some in the world direct their minds outward,
taking Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang as their model,
practicing visualization, gargling, and breath control—
methods like *tuna* and *panrun*—
in their pursuit of longevity.
Others direct their minds inward,
sinking into emptiness and stillness,
becoming dim and lifeless as death itself.

Laozi spoke of ten parts as his standard:
Of those who live, three parts perish;
of those who die, three parts perish#1,
and of the people, some say "all beings."
The Confucian says: "The people are the sprouts of the myriad things."
Yet even among those who seek to nurture life,
three parts perish in the realm of death.
Laozi himself asked: If people nourish life with food and clothing,
why do they perish in the realm of death?
Because they cling excessively to the act of living itself.

Three threes make nine—
all who do not transcend:
those who live cling to being,
those who die cling to non-being,
and the people cling to phenomena.
These three cling to something with their minds,
all dwelling in the realm of life and death.

It is said that those skilled in transcending life
detach from external phenomena,
avoid the two extremes,
and have no attachment at all.
They do not fixate in the mind,
seeing as though not seeing,
coming as though not coming.
Body and mind are as one,
and thus they walk upon land yet meet no rhinoceros or tiger,
enter battle yet are unharmed by weapons.
The rhinoceros—like an ox, blue in color, weighing a thousand *jin*—
has no place to thrust its horn,
the tiger no place to strike with its claws,
the blade no place to lodge its edge.
Thus, fierce beasts and weapons cannot harm them.
Why is this so?
Because their minds are unattached,
and in sitting, standing, moving, or resting,
their minds remain ever empty and still.
Empty means without form,
still means without birth.
Because they are without birth,
they dwell in no place of death.

The Dao gives birth,
virtue nurtures,
things take form,
and circumstances complete them.
Thus, all things do not fail to honor the Dao and revere virtue.
The Dao’s eminence,
virtue’s nobility—
none can bestow these titles,
yet they remain ever natural.

The Dao gives birth and nurtures,
lengthens and matures,
completes and ripens,
nourishes and shelters.
It gives birth yet does not possess,
acts yet does not rely,
lengthens yet does not rule—
this is called the Mysterious Virtue.

All things arise from the Dao and are nurtured by virtue,
their forms shaped by the interplay of giving birth and nurturing,
and thus all things do not fail to honor the Dao and revere virtue.
Moreover, the Dao’s eminence,
virtue’s nobility—
their essence cannot be conferred by rank,
yet they remain ever natural.

Thus, all things are born, nurtured, matured,
completed, ripened, nourished, and sheltered by the Dao.
They arise from the Dao yet are not possessed by it,
are nurtured by virtue yet do not rely upon it,
are lengthened yet are not ruled—
none can bestow these titles,
yet they remain ever natural.
This is called the Mysterious Virtue.

Under Heaven, there is a beginning,
which is the mother of all things.
Having obtained the mother,
one knows her children.
Having known the children,
one returns to guard the mother.
Thus, one’s life will not perish.

Liezi said:
"All that has form arises from the formless."
Thus, the beginning of all things under Heaven is the formless,
and the formless is the mother of all things.
Having obtained the emptiness of the formless as mother,
one knows all things as her children.
Having known the children,
one must return to guard the mother.
If a person can harmonize their mind with the formless,
as a child returns to its mother,
then their life will not perish.

Close the orifices,
shut the gates,
and one will labor no more their whole life.
Open the orifices,
pursue affairs,
and one will never be saved their whole life.

To see small is clarity,
to hold fast to softness is strength.
To use its light,
and return to its clarity—
this leaves no calamity for the body,
and is called "following the constant."

The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind—
these are called the six gates.
Through the six gates, delusive afflictions arise,
and become the door to calamity.
Laozi taught to close the orifices—
the gates are the openings—
and shut the six gates’ doors.
When greed and delusion cease,
one labors no more their whole life.
If one opens the orifices,
pursues affairs,
and admits delusive afflictions,
one will never be saved their whole life.

The six gates take the mind as their root.
If the root is removed,
the phenomena will vanish on their own.
Thus, Laozi said:
"To see small is clarity"—
constantly without desire,
one may be called 'small.'
To hold fast to softness is strength.
The utmost softness under Heaven
responds to things and conforms to customs,
thus using its light.
Within, the mind is empty and still,
and thus returns to its clarity.
'To see small is clarity'—
clarity is like a lamp’s flame,
while light is its outward radiance.
To constrain it is called 'no loss of speech,'
to lose it brings calamity to the body.
Not losing speech is called 'following the constant.'

The Dao makes me distinctly aware—
*zhì* as knowledge, *xíng* as conduct—
and aligns me with the Great Dao,
only to fear its application.
The Great Dao is most level,
yet people prefer narrow paths.
The court is excessively cleared,
fields lie fallow,
granaries are empty,
garments are adorned with embroidery,
belts are girded with sharp blades,
feasts gluttonously indulge,
wealth is hoarded in excess—
this is called boasting of the Dao,
yet it is not the Dao at all.

Zhuangzi said:
"The Dao cannot be questioned,
and questions have no answer."
Thus, the Great Dao transcends speech
and cannot be sought through sight or hearing,
cannot be known through thought or discourse,
cannot be reached through language.
If one applies knowledge, conduct, or speech to the Dao,
then one may truly fear it.

Thus, Laozi said:
"The Dao makes me distinctly aware—
*zhì* as knowledge, *xíng* as conduct—
and aligns me with the Great Dao,
only to fear its application."
Truly, I tell you:
The Great Dao is most level—
plain and without action—
yet people pursue clever shortcuts,
striving for immediate results.
What of the times when courts vaunt cleverness and favor techniques,
when the Dao is neglected,
fields lie fallow,
granaries are empty,
people compete in ornate attire—
garments embroidered with green and white—
and gird themselves with symbols of power like sharp blades,
indulge in gluttonous feasts,
and hoard wealth for surplus—
this is called boasting of the Dao,
yet it is not the Dao at all.

Observing the Way of the age and applying these words—
thus it is worthy of fear.

What is well-established cannot be uprooted,
what is well-embraced cannot be abandoned.
Descendants continue through sacrifice without ceasing.

When cultivated in the self, its virtue becomes true;
when cultivated in the family, its virtue overflows;
when cultivated in the neighborhood, its virtue extends;
when cultivated in the state, its virtue flourishes;
when cultivated in the world, its virtue is universal.

Thus, one observes the self through the self,
the family through the family,
the neighborhood through the neighborhood,
the state through the state,
the world through the world.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

What is well-established in virtue is used without depletion,
what is well-guarded in virtue is held without loss.
Like descendants transmitting sacrifices without end.

When cultivated in the self, its virtue is true;
when cultivated in the family—if all in the family cultivate—its virtue overflows;
when cultivated in the neighborhood—if all in the neighborhood cultivate—its virtue extends;
when cultivated in the state—if all in the state cultivate—its virtue flourishes;
when cultivated in the world—if all in the world cultivate—its virtue is universal.

Thus, one observes the self through the virtue of self-cultivation,
the family through the virtue of family-cultivation,
the neighborhood through the virtue of neighborhood-cultivation,
the state through the virtue of state-cultivation,
the world through the virtue of world-cultivation,
transmitting virtue endlessly,
using it without depletion,
like descendants passing on sacrifices without ceasing.

Laozi said:
How do I know the world is thus?
By this virtue of self-cultivation.

*The True Scripture of Dao and Virtue: Direct Explanation, Scroll Three, completed.*

*The True Scripture of Dao and Virtue: Direct Explanation, Scroll Four*

**#1** *Xiaoqu Da* ["Small Taking Great" — *alternative reading: "Taking the Small to Obtain the Great"*]
**#2** *Suo gui ci Dao zhe, he shi ye* ["What does this Dao/Way value? — *this sentence may be a textual interpolation*"]

The depth of virtue/power is like that of an infant.
Venomous insects do not sting, nor do they bite sharply;
Fierce beasts do not seize it,
Nor do birds of prey snatch—*its grasp is firm and unyielding*.
Its bones are weak, its sinews soft, yet its hold is strong;
It knows not the union of male and female—*yet its essence is supreme*.
It cries all day without its voice breaking—*its harmony is perfect*.
To know harmony is to know constancy,
To know constancy is to know clarity.

To augment life is to bring auspiciousness,
To strain the *qi* by force is to make the body temporarily strong.
When things reach their peak, they grow old—
This is called *not-Dao/Way*,
And *not-Dao/Way* should be abandoned early.

The virtue/power of embracing and nurturing—
When its cultivation is profound,
Its conduct may be likened to that of an infant.
The infant, externally, has no attachments to things,
Internally, has no fixed desires.
Without desires, things cannot sway it—
Thus, venomous insects do not sting,
Fierce beasts do not seize it,
And birds of prey do not snatch its grasp.

The infant’s bones are weak, its sinews soft,
Yet it holds objects firmly with its hands;
It knows not the union of male and female—*yet its vital essence is supreme*.
It cries all day without its voice breaking—*its harmony is perfect*.
To know the infant’s state of no desires,
Its supreme essence, and its perfect harmony—
This is to know constancy,
And knowing constancy is to know clarity.

To fail to grasp this constancy,
To multiply means of augmenting life—
This is called *auspicious calamity*.
Or, to strain the *qi* by force,
To make the body temporarily strong—
This is a contrived method,
Not the true Dao/Way.

When the body is strong and the *qi* is strained,
It is like things relying on their vigor—
Vigor peaks, then decay follows—
This is called *not-Dao/Way*.
Not being the Dao/Way,
It should be abandoned early.

The wise do not speak,
Those who speak are not wise.
Close its *yue* ["cheek/jaw" — *metaphor for excessiveness*],
Shut its door,
Dull its sharpness,
Unravel its entanglements,
Blend its radiance,
Equalize its dust—
This is called *mysterious unity*.

It cannot be drawn near nor kept distant,
Cannot be used for gain nor for harm,
Cannot be exalted nor debased—
Thus, it is held in highest esteem by all under heaven.

Those who awaken to this themselves cannot speak of it;
If they indulge in speech, they do not know it.
To seek the Dao/Way that cannot be spoken,
One must merely close its *yue*,
Shut its door,
Dull the mind’s sharpness,
Unravel the world’s entanglements.
In action, blend its radiance,
In life, equalize its dust—
Constantly responding, yet constantly still—
This is called *mysterious unity of nature*.

Without hatred nor love,
Nearness and distance are naturally balanced,
Gain and harm are naturally removed,
Exaltation and debasement are naturally extinguished—
Thus, all things cannot be drawn near nor kept distant,
Cannot be used for gain nor for harm,
Cannot be exalted nor debased.
All causes cease,
Emotional perceptions are severed,
And it stands effortlessly alone—
Transcending all laws,
Thus it is held in highest esteem by all under heaven.

Govern the state with rectitude,
Employ the *Dao/Way*’s subtlety in warfare—*alternative reading: "strange/uncanny"*,
Gain the world through non-action.
How do I know this to be true?
Under heaven, many taboos exist,
Yet the people grow ever poorer.
Many sharp tools are wielded,
Yet the state grows ever more corrupt;
Many clever artifices are employed,
Yet strange/uncanny deeds multiply;
Laws and decrees grow ever more explicit,
Yet thieves and bandits proliferate.

Thus, the Sage says:
*"I act with non-action, yet the people transform themselves,
I love tranquility, yet the people align with rectitude,
I claim no action, yet the people grow rich,
I desire nothing, yet the people return to simplicity.*
Its governance is veiled and indistinct,
Yet its people are pure and unadulterated;
Its governance is scrutinized and rigid,
Yet its people grow weary and rebellious.
Calamity, ah! is the reverse of fortune,
Fortune, ah! is the foundation of calamity.
Who can know their ultimate limits?
Is it not that they lack rectitude?"*

The rectitude becomes again the uncanonical and the strange,
The good reverts to the demonic.

The people’s confusion—
its duration has long since been established.

Therefore, the Sage is square yet does not cut,
honest yet does not sever,
upright yet does not overstep,
bright yet does not dazzle.

Rectitude is singularity.
When kings and lords attain singularity, they become the rectitude of the world—
thus it is said: *"With rectitude, one governs the world."*

Fortune, misfortune, regret, and blame arise from action,
but singularity alone can conquer and prevail—
thus it is said: *"With the uncanonical and singular, one subdues the world through warfare."*

Sunzi said: *"Thus, one takes the world with non-action."*

Laozi asked: *"How do I know this is so?"*

In the Zhou era, the world was rife with taboos,
people dared not speak of maladies below,
yet the people grew ever poorer;
many sharp tools were wielded for convenience,
and the virtue of the worthy was prized for cleverness—
thus the state grew ever more corrupt;
many clever artifices were employed,
yet useless excesses flourished—
thus strange and uncanny deeds multiplied;
laws and decrees grew ever more explicit,
yet virtue and moral cultivation were neglected—
the people knew no shame,
thus thieves and bandits proliferated.

Therefore, the Sage says:
*"I act with non-action, yet the people transform themselves,
I love tranquility, yet the people align with rectitude,
I claim no action, yet the people grow rich,
I desire nothing, yet the people return to simplicity."*

Thus, to govern the world with non-action,
though its governance is veiled and indistinct,
it does not display its rule—
yet its people are pure and unadulterated, transforming themselves.

If one governs the world with action,
though its governance is scrutinized and rigid,
displaying its rule—
its people grow weary and rebellious, incomplete and unfulfilled.

To save the world with action,
is like the King Tang treating scabies—
temporarily a blessing,
yet scabies thrives because of the poultice.

Indeed, calamity is the reverse of fortune,
and fortune is the foundation of calamity.
Who can know the ultimate logic of their extremes?

「Indeed, those who govern the realm—do they lack rectitude?
Nowadays, the upright are deemed strange, while the perverse are praised as virtuous;
the people are long ensnared in confusion.
Thus, the Sage acts broadly without division,
pure and serene without harshness,
punishes wrongs directly yet does not indulge in retaliation,
and conceals brilliance without ostentation—
all these stem from the state of non-action.

In managing both human affairs and the Dao of Heaven,
nothing surpasses frugality.
Frugality is the essence of *early-complex*—
thus, *early-complex* is born.
*Early-complex* is called the profound embodiment of virtue and the accumulation of *power*—
accumulating *power* ensures nothing is unconquered.
If nothing is unconquered,
yet none know its limit,
then one can establish a state.
A state with such foundation
can endure long.
This is the Dao of deep-rooted stability,
long life and enduring vision.

If one governs with wisdom and discernment,
one loses the proper way—
nothing surpasses frugality.
To possess yet not use is called frugality.
Frugality is the origin of *early-complex* and rectitude—
thus, *early-complex* is born.
*Early-complex* is called the accumulation of supreme virtue.
As the saying goes:
*"Moderation (中庸), as a virtue, is it not supreme?"*
The people have long been few in virtue.
Accumulating supreme virtue ensures no task is unconquered.
To conquer all without haste,
yet none know its limit,
then one can establish a state.
Rectitude is the foundation of a state;
a state with such foundation
can endure long—
this is the Dao of deep-rooted stability,
the roots and foundation of wood,
which brings long life and enduring vision.

As for governing one’s own person,
one must embrace unity.
Unity is the origin of form—
this is the Dao of deep-rooted stability,
long life, abiding in the world,
preserving form, and enduring vision.
But if one takes unity as the law,
then no task is unconquered.

To govern a great state,
one must treat it as if boiling a small fish—
*[i.e., with gentle, non-intrusive care]*.
Those who govern the world with the Dao of non-action
have no fearsome ghosts.
Not that their ghosts are not fearsome,
but that their fearsome nature does not harm people;
not that their fearsome nature does not harm people,
but that the Sage also does not harm people.
When both do not harm each other,
then virtue returns in harmony.
To govern a great state as if boiling a small fish
means one must not disturb it.
Disturbing it harms the fish,
so those who govern with the Dao of non-action
do not harm the people.
As for ghosts and spirits harming people—
not only do the ghosts not harm them,
but the Heavenly spirits also do not bring pestilence, famine, or drought to harm them.
When spirits and ghosts do not harm people,
it is because the Sage governs with the Dao of non-action
and thus does not harm people either.
For when human and spiritual realms—
both hidden and manifest—
do not harm each other,
then non-action aligns with the virtue of Heaven and Earth,
ghosts and spirits—
virtue converges and returns in harmony.

Thus, those who govern the world with non-action
face no Heavenly resentment,
no human criticism,
no ghostly reproach.
A great state is the confluence of all lands,
the gathering of the world,
the receptive feminine principle of the world.
The feminine principle is ever victorious over the masculine through stillness,
and stillness is the yielding, receptive way.
Thus, a great state yields to small states,
and the small states submit to it;
a small state yields to great states,
and the great states embrace it.
Hence, sometimes yielding brings conquest,
sometimes yielding brings submission.
A great state seeks only to nurture and shelter its people—
this is the joy of Heaven.
A small state seeks only to serve and submit to others—
this is the fear of Heaven.
Mencius said:
*"Those who take joy in Heaven preserve the world,
those who fear Heaven preserve their own state."*
Both attain their desires—
thus, those in great states must not rely on strength,
but rather on yielding.

The Dao is the hidden mystery of all things,
the treasure of the virtuous,
and the refuge of the unvirtuous.
Fine words can be sold like goods in the market,
and noble deeds can be bestowed like the *xing* [杏] fruit.
If people are unvirtuous,
why would one abandon them?
Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven,
and appointing the Three Exalted Ministers,
even if one is offered a jade tablet with a bow
or four horses in advance,
it is not as valuable as simply receiving this Dao.
Why did the ancients hold this Dao in such esteem?
Was it not because they sought it to obtain,
or pardoned crimes to escape?
Thus, it is held in esteem by all under Heaven.
The Dao is the hidden mystery of all things.
The virtuous cherish the Dao as a treasure,
while the unvirtuous rely on virtue as their refuge.
Thus, honoring the Dao as fine words,
following it can be as effortless as selling in the market;
virtue as noble deeds,
can be bestowed upon people.
If people do not embrace virtue and the Dao,
why would one abandon them?
Thus, like Yao yielding the throne to Xu You,
and setting him as Son of Heaven,
or Chu appointing Zhuang Zhou as Three Exalted Minister,
though invited with jade tablets and noble gifts,
though given carriages of ministers and the honor of horses,
they declined and withdrew—
this was not as valuable as simply receiving this Dao.

But why did the ancients esteem this Dao?
What was the reason they esteemed this Dao?
The reason they esteemed it
was that the heart harbors no desires.
They viewed honor and splendor as dust and filth,
and did not say,
*"I seek it to obtain,"*
or *"I cling to it to escape crime."*
Thus, it is held in esteem by all under Heaven.

To act without acting,
to do without doing,
to savor without savoring—
great or small, many or few,
repaying resentment with virtue.
The Sage acts without acting,
dwelling in the realm of doing nothing—
this is the virtue of serenity and ease,
its flavor without savoring.»

The great and the small—
speaking of their forms, many and few,
speaking of their numbers—
when clinging to dust and illusory attachments,
one can become the object of resentment.
Thus, acting with no mind,
it is said one repays resentment with virtue.

To tackle difficulty in its ease,
to achieve greatness in its smallness—
the difficult matters of the world must begin in ease,
the great undertakings of the world must begin in smallness.
Thus, the Sage never acts in greatness,
and so is able to accomplish greatness.

Those who seek to tackle difficulty
must first attend to its ease.
Those who seek to achieve greatness
must first attend to its smallness.

The world’s difficult matters must be done in ease,
the world’s great matters must be done in smallness—
thus, the Sage does nothing,
never acts in greatness,
and so is able to accomplish greatness.

Light promises bring few fulfillments,
many easinesses bring many difficulties—
thus, the Sage proceeds with difficulty,
and so in the end encounters no difficulty.

Light promises, once given, are seldom kept.
From many easinesses come many difficulties—
thus, the Sage responds to the world
by embracing difficulty,
and so in the end encounters no difficulty.

What is stable is easy to hold,
what is yet unmanifest is easy to plan,
what is fragile is easy to shatter,
what is subtle is easy to disperse.

Act before it exists,
govern before it is disordered.
A tree thick enough to embrace
begins as a sprout;
a nine-tiered tower
begins with a clod of earth;
a thousand-li journey
begins beneath one’s feet.

The doer brings about failure,
the grasper brings about loss—
thus, the Sage acts without acting,
and so knows no failure;
holds without grasping,
and so knows no loss.

Therefore, when the people engage in affairs,
they often ruin them when nearly complete.
If one treats the end as the beginning,
there will be no ruined undertakings.

Thus, the Sage desires without desiring,
does not prize hard-to-obtain treasures;
learns without learning,
to correct the errors of the common folk,
to assist the natural unfolding of all things,
and dares not act.

What is stable is easy to preserve when perilous,
what is yet unmanifest is easy to plan when already formed,
what is thin and fragile is easy to shatter and disperse—
for what is subtle is easily scattered.

All things must be acted upon before they arise,
governed before they are disordered.
A tree thick enough to embrace grows from a sprout,
a nine-tiered tower rises from a clod of earth,
a thousand-li journey begins beneath one’s feet—
all things grow from the subtle to the great,
and must not be neglected.

All who act bring about failure,
all who grasp bring about loss—
thus, the Sage acts without acting,
and so knows no failure;
holds without grasping,
and so knows no loss.

Therefore, when the people engage in affairs,
they often ruin them when nearly complete.
*Ji* is the subtle movement of the heart.
Before the heart moves, it dwells in the nameless void;
when *ji* moves, it reveals itself—
yet it is still not called *ji*.
*Ji* is when the heart first departs from the void and enters being,
the subtle threshold of desire’s beginning,
the start of all things.

If one treats the end as the beginning,
there will be no ruined undertakings.

Thus, the Sage desires without desiring—
cautious of the heart’s subtle stirrings.
Does not prize hard-to-obtain treasures—
cautious of the world’s subtle movements.
Thus, the Sage’s learning
does not rely on discerning *ji* to learn,
but corrects the common folk’s errors,
assists the natural order of all things,
and dares not act.

The ancients who excelled in the Dao
did not seek to enlighten the people,
but rather to make them simple.
The people are difficult to govern
because their cleverness is excessive.
Thus, governing with cleverness is the ruin of the state;
not governing with cleverness is the state’s blessing.
Knowing these two is the standard.
To always know the standard
is called the Mysterious Virtue.

The Mysterious Virtue is profound and distant,
contrary to the ways of things—
and only then does one attain the Great Harmony.

The ancients who excelled in the Dao and governed the world
did not use cleverness to enlighten the people,
nor cleverness to rule the world—
they sought to make the people simple.
The people are difficult to govern
because their cleverness is excessive.
Thus, governing with cleverness is the ruin of the state;
not governing with cleverness is the state’s blessing.
Knowing these two is the standard.
To always know the standard
is called the Mysterious Virtue.

The logic of the Mysterious Virtue is profound and distant,
contrary to the ways of things.
Not using cleverness to enlighten the people,
only then does one attain the Great Harmony of the world.

The rivers and seas become kings of the valleys
because they excel in yielding—
thus, they become kings of the valleys.

Therefore, the Sage who wishes to be above others
speaks from below;
who wishes to lead others
places himself behind.

Thus, the Sage stands above yet the people do not grow weary of him,
his voice resounds in front yet they are not harmed by it—
therefore, the world gladly follows his Dao and never tires.

Because he does not contend,
none under heaven can contend with him.

The rivers and seas so become kings of the valleys,
because they excel in dwelling below—
thus, they become kings of the valleys.

Therefore, the Sage who wishes to be above others
speaks in humility below;
who wishes to lead others
places himself behind, yielding to them.

Thus, the Sage stands above yet the people do not grow weary of him,
and leads yet they are not harmed—
because of his yielding and non-contention with all things,
none under heaven can contend with him.

All under heaven say my Dao is vast,
yet seems unorthodox.
Only because it is vast
does it seem unorthodox.
If it seemed orthodox for long,
then it would be trifling indeed.

Laozi says: *"All under heaven say my Dao is vast,"*
because it does not adhere to forms, names, or measures.
If it seems similar,
it will never truly be so.

It seems vast only because of the singularity of its *qi*—
yet when confined to forms, names, and measures,
it will never truly be so.

The ancients said:
*"Similar is similar, yet it is not the same."*

If it were truly the same,
it would be long since trivialized.

*夫* (this particle, emphasizing contrast),
students must discern:
if the heart harbors even a hair’s breadth of attachment,
thought, or calculation,
it remains within the realm of forms, names, and measures—
thus, the cycle of birth and death persists.
Hence, the ancient Sage left this sincere admonition.

I possess three treasures; I hold them fast.
The first is *cí* (compassion),
the second is *jiǎn* (frugality),
the third is *"not daring to be first under heaven"* (humility in action).

*Cí* (compassion) brings forth courage;
frugality brings forth abundance;
not daring to be first under heaven
allows one to fulfill great tasks and endure.

Now, abandon *cí* and take courage instead—
courage harms others.
Abandon frugality and take abundance instead—
abundance injures *virtue*.
Abandon humility and take being first instead—
others will resent you.

To harm others, injure *virtue*, and invite resentment—
this is the path of death.

When wielding arms,
compassion and non-contention are the Way of Heaven.
To use compassion in battle is upright;
to hold firm with compassion is steadfast.
If Heaven intends to save them,
it shields them with compassion.

The skilled warrior does not rely on force,
the skilled fighter does not rage,
the skilled victor does not contend,
the skilled leader places himself below others.

This is called the *virtue* of non-contention,
this is called the power of leading others—
both are called *"harmonizing with Heaven,"*
the ultimate *virtue* of antiquity.

The ancients spoke of wielding arms:
*"I dare not be the aggressor but only the defender,
nor advance an inch when I must retreat a foot."*

This is called *"having no path yet following the path,"*
*"brandishing no arms yet defending with arms,"*
*"confronting no enemy yet overcoming them,"*
*"grasping no weapons yet wielding them."*

No calamity is greater than underestimating an enemy—
to underestimate an enemy is to risk losing my treasures.
Thus, when two armies clash,
the one that shows compassion and pity will prevail.

My words are easy to know,
easy to practice.
Yet none under heaven can know them,
none can practice them.

Words have a root,
affairs have a master.
Only because of my lack of adherence,
none know my root.

Few know me,
so I am honored.
Thus, the Sage wears coarse garments while cherishing the precious Dao.

Laozi says:
*"My words are simple and direct, easy to know;
my actions require no force, easy to practice.*
Yet people, with their attachments and calculations,
seek to see, hear, do, and gain—
so none can know, none can practice.

This book speaks of *virtue* with its root,
discusses affairs with their master.
Only because of my lack of adherence to
the root of words and the master of affairs,
Laozi says, *"Thus, none know my Dao."*

Few know my Dao,
and they sigh: *"Then my Dao is noble—
the most exalted of all."*

Thus, the Sage wears coarse garments,
like the humble attire of the poor,
while inwardly holding the supreme Dao
as precious as jade.

Like jade hidden in stone,
only its outer form is seen,
rarely its inner worth.
To know what is unknown is noble;
to not know what is known is ill.

The Sage’s illness lies in his knowing of illness—
thus he does not fall ill.
The Sage’s freedom from illness comes from his knowing of illness—
thus he does not fall ill.

*The Scripture of Purity and Stillness* says:
To inwardly observe the mind is to know.
The mind without its own essence is ignorance.
To awaken to the mind’s lack of essence—
this is the noble way.

The Dao is the mind ever without thought or desire,
silently unaware of its own dwelling.
If one knows this, it is illness.
Only by recognizing knowing as illness
does one escape the hindrance of being known—
thus one does not fall ill.
The Sage’s freedom from illness comes from his knowing knowing as illness—
thus he does not fall ill.

When the people do not fear great authority,
great authority arrives.
Do not confine your dwelling,
do not weary of your birth.
Only by not wearying
does one not weary.
Thus the Sage knows himself but does not display himself,
loves himself but does not exalt himself—
so he discards the former and takes the latter.

The people, their hearts empty and still,
all phenomena naturally vanish—
thus they do not fear the threats of all things,
and know that great authority has come.

Admonish them: Do not cling to petty perceptions,
do not narrow your dwelling.
Do not resent dust and toil,
do not weary of your birth.
Only by not wearying
does one, though having a body for gain,
awaken to the truth of emptiness and constancy—
thus one cherishes oneself and does not weary.

The ancients said:
Though the five aggregates remain whole,
who knows where to seek the scattered bones afterward?
Thus the Sage knows himself but does not display himself,
is humble in love but does not exalt himself—
for pride is in self-display and self-exaltation.
So he discards that and takes this: self-knowledge and self-love.

To dare boldly is to court death;
to dare not to dare is to live.
These two—
one brings benefit, one harm.
What the Heaven detests—
who knows its reason?
Thus the Sage follows the difficult path.

The Way of Heaven,
though not contending, wins well;
though not speaking, responds well;
though not summoned, comes of its own accord—
open and yet well-plotted.
The Heavenly net is vast,
spread wide yet nothing is lost.

To dare boldly invites death—harm;
to dare not to dare brings life—benefit.
These two—
one brings benefit, one harm,
like what Heaven detests—
yet who knows its reason?
The principle of response and provocation—
thus the Sage follows the difficult path.

The Way of Heaven,
though not contending, yet wins well;
though not speaking, yet responds well;
though not summoned, yet comes in reply.
The Way of Heaven is open yet as if well-plotted,
so that good and evil cannot escape—
like Heaven’s net, though vast and wide,
punishes evil and rewards virtue without loss of a hair.

The people do not ordinarily fear death—
how can you use death to frighten them?
If you make the people fear death and act strangely,
I could seize and kill them—who would dare?
There are always those charged with killing who kill.
If you substitute for those who kill and kill,
it is like substituting for the master carpenter to hew—
if you do not substitute for the master carpenter,
few will avoid injuring their hands.

The people’s desires are naturally strange—
thus they do not ordinarily fear death.
How can you, with your lamentations and laws,
use death to frighten them?
If you make the people forget desire and always fear death,
and among them there are those who act strangely,
saying, *"I could seize and kill them to warn the crowd—who would dare?"*
Yet those who act strangely because of their desires
will inevitably invite their own calamity.
There are always those Heaven has charged with killing who kill—
why must you substitute for Heaven in executing punishment?
Not only do you harm living beings,
but you also disrupt the harmony of Heaven itself.
To substitute for those who kill is like substituting for the master carpenter—
the carpenter, substituting for the master,
labors with axe and adze—
few will avoid injuring their hands.
To rule the world with punishments alone
is rare not to stray from the Way.

The people’s hunger comes from their rulers’ excessive taxation—
thus it is difficult to govern the hungry.
The people’s difficulty in being governed comes from their rulers’ actions—
thus it is difficult to govern.
The people’s recklessness in facing death comes from their rulers’ excessive provision for life—
thus they treat death lightly.
Only those who do not overindulge in providing for life
are superior to those who value life above all.

In the Zhou era, the people’s hunger and insufficiency
came from their rulers’ broad consumption,
necessitating heavy taxation—
thus they were hungry.
The people’s stubbornness and difficulty in being governed
came from their rulers’ actions—
thus they were difficult to govern.
The people’s daring to risk death
came from their rulers’ excessive provision for life—
thus they treated death lightly.
Only those who do not overindulge in providing for life
are superior to those who value all life under Heaven.

Life is soft and weak,
death is hard and strong.
Grass and trees in life are soft and fragile,
in death they wither and decay.
Thus, the hard and strong are the companions of death,
the soft and weak are the companions of life.
Therefore, strong armies do not conquer,
rigid wood is easily split.
Thus, the hard and strong are lowly,
the soft and weak are exalted.

The Way of Heaven—
is it like drawing a bow?
The high are lowered,
the low are raised,
the excessive are diminished,
the insufficient are supplemented.
The Way of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the insufficient.
But the Way of humanity is otherwise:
it diminishes the insufficient to serve the excessive.
Who can diminish the excessive to serve the insufficient in the world?
Only the Dao can do so.
Thus the Sage acts without relying on it,
completes the work without taking credit—
does he not wish to be seen as virtuous?

The Way of Heaven diminishes the excessive and supplements the insufficient,
yet the Way of humanity is otherwise—
it diminishes the insufficient to serve the excessive.
Who then can diminish the excessive to serve the insufficient in the world?
Only by following the Way of Heaven can this be done.

Thus the Sage follows the Way of Heaven,
acts without relying on it,
completes the work without taking credit—
is this not because he does not wish to be seen as virtuous?

Nothing in the world is softer and weaker than water,
yet in attacking the hard and strong, none can surpass it—
for there is nothing to replace it.
The soft overcomes the hard,
the weak overcomes the strong—
yet though all know this, none can practice it.

Therefore the Sage says:
*"To bear the nation’s defilement is called the Lord of the Soil Altars;
to bear the nation’s calamities is called the King of the World."*
Straight speech seems contrary.

Nothing surpasses the soft and weak like water,
yet in attacking the hard and strong, none can excel it—
to replace it is impossible,
for there is nothing to replace it.
Though all know that the soft overcomes the hard,
the weak overcomes the strong,
yet none can practice it—
for they cannot endure humiliation and remain soft.

Thus the Sage says:
*"When Tang and Wu spoke of the myriad regions as the Lord of the Soil Altars,
they alone called themselves ‘Orphaned, Aged, and Unworthy’—
able to bear the nation’s guilt upon themselves alone.
To bear the nation’s defilement is called calamity;
to bear the nation’s defilement is called the King of the World."*
This is straight speech aligning with virtue,
though the common folk see it as contrary.

To reconcile great grievances,
there must be lingering resentment—
how then can it be called good?
Thus the Sage holds only the left contract,
demanding nothing from others.
Therefore, the virtuous keep the left contract,
the unvirtuous demand the right.

The Way of Heaven has no favorites,
always aiding those who do good without action.
Tang expelled Jie, Wu Wang attacked Zhou,
yet in reconciling the world’s great grievances,
there would later be retaliatory wars.
With lingering resentment, how can it be called good?
Thus the Sage acts in non-action,
like holding the left contract—
the left contract is held alone,
the right contract is given to others.
The left and right contracts together form trust,
yet no demands are made of others.

The virtuous, like the keeper of the left contract,
receive things naturally—this is the Way of Heaven.
The unvirtuous, like the keeper of the right contract,
demand things to be fulfilled—this is the Way of humanity.
The Way of Heaven favors none,
always aiding those who act without doing.

In small states with few people,
let the people have ten or a hundredfold tools but not use them,
let them value death and not move far.
Though there are boats and carriages, they have no use for them;
though there are armor and weapons, they have no need to display them;
let them return to knotted cords for record-keeping.
Let their food be simple, their clothing plain,
their customs settled, their work joyful.
Though neighboring states are close enough to hear roosters and dogs,
let the people live to old age without visiting one another.

The heart is originally pure and still,
untainted by nature.
When desire arises in the heart,
it clings to the myriad things,
and once it clings, it gives rise to seeking.
Laozi wished for the world to have no desires,
no clinging to the myriad things—
thus in small states with few people,
let the people have tools for tens or hundreds,
yet those who could govern are not employed.
If the people have no songs,
their hearts are tranquil and at ease,
forgetting all matters of profit and loss,
thus valuing death and not moving far.
Without desire, there is no seeking—
though there are boats and carriages, they have no use for them.
Without desire, there is no strife—
though there are armor and weapons, they have no need to display them.
Returning to simplicity, they do not rely on writing or contracts,
letting the people live as in the age of the Three Sovereigns,
using knotted cords once more.
Without desire, they do not crave rich flavors yet find their food sweet,
do not adorn their clothing yet find it beautiful,
live in simplicity and find their customs settled,
do not envy others and find their work joyful.
Though neighboring states are close enough to hear roosters and dogs,
with no desires or seeking,
even if they meet, the people live to old age without visiting one another.

The ruler is content and unassuming, doing nothing,
the people are sincere and unassuming, doing nothing—
then why use tools for tens or hundreds?
Truthful words are not ornate,
ornate words are not truthful.
Truthful words lack the beauty of the common tongue,
ornate words are extravagant yet lack truth.
The good do not argue,
those who argue are not good.
The Sage of the Way acts rather than argues—
those who delight in argument do not act in goodness.

*The Analects* says:
*"The gentleman desires to be slow in speech and swift in action."*
The wise are not learned,
the learned are not wise.
The wise understand the heart’s nature,
not in vast knowledge or broad learning.
Those who pursue broad learning
often lack true understanding.

Confucius said:
*"Zigong, do you think I am someone who studies much and remembers it?"*
Zigong replied:
*"Yes, is it not so?"*
Confucius said:
*"No. I have one thread that runs through it all."*

The Sage has no accumulation—
the more he gives to others, the more he possesses;
the more he gives to others, the broader his Way becomes.
Confucius said:
*"You disciples think I conceal things?
I conceal nothing from my ears."*

The Sage has no accumulation,
wishing others to entrust him with care.
The more he gives to others, the more he gains;
the more he gives to others, the broader his Way becomes—
thus benefiting others while also benefiting himself.

The Way of Heaven benefits without harming;
the Way of the Sage acts without contending.

The *Daodejing* concludes with these two lines,
to complete its virtue.

The Way of Heaven benefits without harming;
the Way of the Sage acts without contending.

When Yuan Qing paid homage to Master Benlai, Deng Guang of Wangwu requested this text, wishing to engrave it for the world. Master Benlai said:

*"This book was written to remind myself of what I might forget. Now, people who read books on Dao and virtue often retreat and humble themselves, fearing they cannot practice it."*

Guang said:
*"When qi aligns with form and spirit, and one can grasp yin and yang, then life spans with Heaven and Earth—worn yet never ending. This is called the True Person (Zhenren).

If one takes the One as the principle and applies it to all things, then one may roam between Heaven and Earth, perceiving and hearing beyond the eight directions. This is the manifestation of pure virtue and the preservation of the Way—called the Perfect Person (Zhiren).

The next level takes yin and yang as the principle, follows the logic of the eight winds, and dwells in the harmony of Heaven and Earth. Within, there are no resentful, angry, or enraged thoughts. Thus, one may adapt to desires in the world and live to a hundred years or more—this is called the Sage.

If one models oneself after Heaven and Earth, resembles the sun and moon, and arranges the constellations and stars to create celestial texts, records the solar cycles, observes yin and yang’s reversals and compliance, establishes laws and calendars, and distinguishes the four seasons—this is called the Virtuous Person (Xianren).

The next level conforms to the Five Constants and a hundred virtues—this is called the Gentleman (Junzi).

To abandon the Gentleman’s conduct is to be a petty person (xiaoren).

From the True Person down to the Gentleman, none depart from the One qi, yin and yang, and human affairs—all are called virtue.

If you speak of the Great Dao of non-action before the One qi to those cultivating virtue, even the Three Worthies and Ten Sages would still harbor doubt—how much more so for petty people?

The Five Constants and a hundred virtues are already the virtues of human conduct; if people refuse to practice even these, how much more would they shrink from the Great Dao? What is there to fear?"*

Master Benlai said:
*"There was once a traveler who said: In the past, Wang Xu registered the *Daodejing*, yet died young. His father pursued his spirit and saw him wearing an iron shackle, saying, ‘I should not have registered the *Daodejing*, so I suffer this punishment.’ If this is true, then the book must be difficult to practice."*

Guang said:
*"Examining Xu’s registration, though it strayed from the Way, it was not entirely without virtue. If people followed its virtue, it could still benefit the world.

For example, Liu Qi composed musical chapters, collecting phrases from leisurely outings and discarded lines—merely capturing emotions and scenes, leading people to indulge in desires, chase pleasures, and drown in wine and lust, obscuring their true nature and burying morality. When heard in private chambers, it stirs emotions and provokes actions—peeping through cracks, scaling walls to follow one another, corrupting propriety. What difference is there between this and luring people into ravines?

To hold the office of a layer yet perform the deeds of a clown, claiming to be a scholar yet failing to uphold the Way of the Ancestral Teachers, leaving licentious words in the world to blind the ignorant—this is to invert the Way of the Ancestral Teachers. Moreover, which of these two bears greater guilt?

Those who deceive with false teachings invite slander upon themselves, while true teachings cannot be easily ruined. Why fear their ridicule?"*

Master Benlai said:
*"Even today, people are still amazed by wonders—like He Shang Gong ascending to Heaven, Liezi riding the wind, turning stones into gold, or going a year without food, with red faces and black hair. Such tales make people gaze in awe.

Yet I now live in poverty in a humble lane, my hair streaked with gray, selling medicine in the market, supporting my wife and children—just like everyone else. If I were to show this book to people, it would surely invite slanderous speech."*

Guang said:
*"The world speaks of Shun dwelling at Lì Shān, where the ox tilled and the birds weeded—this was the virtue/power of the Sage that moved and summoned them. 

Master Lù Guīméng replied:
*"This is a strange technique—how can it be called the virtue/power of a Sage?"

Confucius, recounting the text of Shun, said:
*"He expanded wisdom and refined culture—here the virtue/power of the Sage reached its limit. Why speak of such summoning? It is like the Great Achievement (Dàchéng) only after being recommended to Heaven.

Mencius said:
*"Emperor Yáo and Shun were no different from ordinary people, yet those who love sensational tales exaggerate their marvels—this is not the true intent of the Sage. For instance, when Emperor Wén of Hàn encountered He Shang Gong, the Master ascended to Heaven as described, rising a hundred zàng above the earth before speaking with the Emperor. If one could truly do this, it would be a strange technique—yet again, this is the exaggeration of those who love sensational tales.

Liezi could harmonize the Six Qi (liúhé) and merge with the luminous clarity (yījīngmíng), so that his mind became concentrated and his form dissolved, his bones and flesh entirely blending—floating east and west like a dry leaf or husk, yet he never knew whether the wind carried him or he carried the wind. The wind and I both forgot this distinction—how could he truly have walked upon the void and ridden the wind?"*

「Indeed. To ride the wind and walk upon the void is the art of lightness; to transmute stones into gold is the art of transformation; to abstain from food for years is the art of grain-cutting; to have a red face and black hair is the art of cultivation—all these are mere techniques, not the Dao/Way of virtue/power.

The true practitioner of the Dao/Way of virtue/power, like Liezi dwelling in Zheng, also had his fields to till. When Master Ziyang left him grain, Liezi refused it. His wife, pressing her heart in sorrow, revealed their poverty—yet he still had a wife and children. For forty years in Zheng, the ruler and ministers treated him like any commoner, indistinguishable from the vulgar masses. Yet the Dao/Way of virtue/power lies not in outward appearance, but in the mind.

The vulgar only judge by outward circumstances, yet they fail to grasp the heart. For instance, when Zhuangzi hosted Confucius and they encountered the bandit Zhi, Zhi assessed them by worldly affairs, so they could not escape the defamation of the petty.

The *Southern Blossom Scripture* says: "To speak of the Dao/Way but not follow its proper order is not the Dao/Way; to speak of the Dao/Way but not grasp its essence is mere idle quotation." Now, the Master before you established a ladder of virtue/power to reveal its order, and did not explain the Dao/Way through techniques and spells—this is worthy of attention.

To expound this *Scripture* directly, its language is plain yet its meaning profound; its examples are clear, its teachings explicit—yet the world has never seen such a work. If one claims to act solely for oneself, how did the Ancestral Teachers benefit others? Let me clarify the essential words: the Master, who sat in silence for long, then spoke: "Five thousand words, yet their essence lies in the two characters: *no desire* (无欲). The seeker of the Dao/Way must only keep *no desire* in their heart—this is the supreme Dao/Way.

Yet the meaning of *no desire* is exceedingly profound. Therefore, Laozi first speaks of *no desire* in his opening chapter; fearing students would cling to the idea of *nothingness*, he then speaks of *desire* (有欲); again fearing they would be ensnared by *desire*, he declares that the union of *having* and *not having* is called *mysterious* (玄); and again fearing they would fixate on *mysterious*, he adds *yet again mysterious* (又玄). Those who brush aside these four stages are said to enter the Dao/Way’s gate.

Yet students often cling to one of these stages and thereby fall ill. First, when students hear *no desire*, they seek to sever thoughts in their mind and attain *no desire*, not realizing that severing thoughts *is* desire itself—this clinging to *nothingness* is a sickness. Second, when they seek *desire* in their mind, they believe there exists something separate from the mind called *desire*—yet they fail to know that *desire* is the mind itself, and the mind is *desire*. The moment they hold onto the notion of *desire* within the mind, it becomes desire—this clinging to *having* is also a sickness. Third, when they force their mind to be still and concentrated, like a wooden statue, unmoving and tranquil—this clinging to *mysterious* is called the sickness of *both having and not having*. Fourth, when they brush aside the traces of *mysterious* and act without attachment, dissolving the duality of subject and object in their mind—this clinging to *yet again mysterious* is called the sickness of *neither having nor not having*.

All these above are entanglements of the mind, and they are all defilements—thus, they are sicknesses. Only when one’s mind is free of these four afflictions can they truly be said to have *no desire*.

Now, those who study the Dao/Way and annotate texts still cannot escape the realm of words, mistaking *mysterious* for the Dao/Way itself, and *yet again mysterious* as the gateway to all wonders—this is truly erroneous. To write of the Dao/Way, one must reveal its true teaching, which lies beyond these four stages. The Dao/Way is the gateway to all wonders, yet texts rely on words to convey it—how can one cling to words and claim to understand?

The student of the Dao/Way must only abandon the slightest trace of grasping thoughts. Their mind should be as vast as the bright sky, ever dwelling in emptiness, without a speck of dust. Light and clarity permeate all things, and then they respond to affairs as they arise—like clouds forming in the sky, appearing and disappearing without a trace, leaving no mark. Their mind is unattached to anything—this is called *virtue/power* (德).

It is said: *No taking, no discarding; no mundane, no sage; no single law to cultivate, no action to attain*—thus, it is called *ordinary mind* (平常心). The Dao/Way also says: *A single mind unborn, all dharmas are without blame*.

Students often doubt this, fearing they will fall into *emptiness*—so they turn back, gazing at the cliff. This is not falling into *emptiness*, but attaining the mind of *no mind* (无心). To truly grasp *no mind*, one is called a Dao/Way person (道人). The Dao/Way person stands above the True Person (真人), for the True Person clings to notions of subject and object in their practice, and thus remains below the Dao/Way person.

At that time, in the year *Gēnchén* of the *Shaoxing* era, a man from Yǐngchuān named **Chén Yuánqīng** recorded his words and appended them here.」

chunks.original_text: 道德真经直解 经名：道德真经直解。 宋邵若愚解。 四卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 道德真经直解叙事 据《史记》略曰：老子为守藏室之史，周衰，遂去。 关令尹喜曰：子将隐矣，强为我着书。 上下篇，#1 言道德之意五千余言而去，莫知其终。 缘其史有上下篇目之文，后人因之，上卷说道，下卷说德。 今以理考，道德混说，无上下篇，此史辞之流言，今以除去。 又不知何人不审正文前后本意，分为八十一章，惟务其华，图象阳数，此以戏论，无益於人，今亦除去。 又创立篇名，狭居其事，言理不当，今亦除去。 此书义不连环者，当时关令不解征问，而老子自陈其事，或引前圣之语，所以文意断续，其辞重迭者，如父母慈心，训之切切。 其间干涉国务者，盖老子叹当时之风，乃周朝之事也。 其间犯讳，若改易之，经久恐失本意。 据今云经史旧文，则不避及，书籍传录，为字不成。 此书笺注者多，虽能於理则不中，虽辩於事则无法。 只如注玄牝为口鼻，是不中理也。 死之徒为涅盘梵语涅盘，秦译无为。 是不中事也。 如是胸怀臆注，语言散失者，不欲备举，其由未至於道也。
