chunks.original_text: 施心於事，尚不能久，况乎其在道也？ 即心见道，见道离心，有心则有碍。 喻如即食得饱，饱当离食，故曰余食赘碍其行。 所行为行物事也尚或恶之，况乎其在道也？ 故有道者不处也。 有物混成，先天地生，寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不殆，可以为天下母。 吾不知其名，字之曰道，强为之名曰大。 大曰逝，逝曰远，远曰返。 故道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 域中有四大，而王处一焉。 人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然。 大道虚无也。 虚无无物，自然生有，以一气为有物之称，天地万类，普因一气而混成，先在天地阴阳也以前生。 寂兮言无声也，寥兮言无形也，独立於万物之上而不改易也，周行六合而不殆止也，万物皆自一生，可以为天下母。 虽云有物，寂兮寥兮，亦是无称之称。 老子云吾不知其名，以字记之曰道，强为之名曰大。 推大之理往逝之，故曰逝往也。 逝四方上下，其理弥远，故曰远。 远则不可推，复返於一，故曰返。 夫万物因一而生，故道大也。 万物因阴阳化形，故天大、地大也。 又云王亦大者，谓虚无为域，域中有此四大，而王以道莅天下而处一焉。 人以五常百行修身，而从谦下由取法於地，地之生育取法於天，天之运化取法於一气之道，一气之道取法於虚无自然。 重为轻根，静为躁君。 是以君子终日行不离辎重。 虽有荣观，燕处超然。 如何万乘之主而以身轻天下。 轻则失臣，躁则失君。 重为轻之根，静为躁动也之君主也。 以事言之，是以君子终日行者，欲轻亦不离辎重之车。 虽有荣观，在物必依燕处之静，超然可见。 轻不离重，动不离静，君不离民，如何感叹之意万乘之主而以身贵高而轻天下。 轻天下则失臣，民也躁动也则失君。 善行音衡无辙迹，善言无瑕谪，善计不用筹算，善闭无关键而不可开，善结无绳约而不可解。 是以圣人常善救人，故无 弃人； 常善救物，故无弃物。 是谓袭明。 故善人，不善人之师； 不善人，善人之资。 不贵其师，不爱其资，虽智大迷，是谓要妙。 善行其道者无辙迹，车行之迹此所谓行无行，行故无迹。 善言其道者无瑕谪，此所谓言无言，言故无瑕谪。 善计其道者，其心无思无为，故不用筹算。 善闭其道者，心常无欲，则境莫能入，虽无关键锁类而不可开。 善结继也其道者，达自心是道，虽无绳继约束而不可解。 是以圣人常以此善救人，故无弃人； 常以此善普同救物，故无弃物。 如是自利利他，是谓袭明。 故善道人为不善道人之师，不善道人得善道人之所资。 然当不贵其师，不爱其资，若贵师爱资，虽为权智，执之同於大迷。 无智无得，是谓要妙。 知其雄，守其雌，为天下溪音溪。 为天下溪，常德不离，复归於婴儿。 知其白，守其黑，为天下式。 为天下式，常德不武，复归於无极。 知其荣，守其辱，为天下谷。 为天下谷，常德乃足，复归於朴。 学人未能全得无心之道者，但知其雄强胜物。 而守其柔雌之道，老子喻为天下溪，谓处下而不争也。 能为天下溪，常使其德不离，久则复归於婴儿。 婴儿谓睹境无心知其自理明白，守其黑默之道者，可为天下式，法也谓藏光隐德也。 能为天下式，常使其德不忒，失也久则其德复归於无极。 尽也知其荣而不喜，守其辱而不忧，譬为天下空谷，谓虚而能容也。
chunks.translated_text:
「When the mind is applied to affairs,
it still cannot endure for long—
how much less when applied to the Dao?

If the mind clings to the Dao,
the Dao departs from the mind,
and where there is mind, there is obstruction.

It is like grasping food to achieve satiety—
once sated, one must depart from food,
yet it is said: *Excessive food and superfluous actions*
hinder one’s progress.
Even ordinary actions may be resented—
how much more so when applied to the Dao?

Thus, the Daoist does not dwell there.

There is a primal substance (*mixed and unified*),
born before heaven and earth,
silent and vast,
standing alone yet unchanging,
circulating endlessly yet never exhausted.
It may be called the Mother of all under heaven.

I do not know its name,
so I call it *Dao* and boldly name it *Great*.
*Great* is passing,
passing is distant,
distant is returning.
Hence, the Dao is Great,
heaven is Great,
earth is Great,
and the Sage-King is also Great.

Within the realm of the four Great ones,
the Sage-King occupies one.
Humans follow earth,
earth follows heaven,
heaven follows the Dao,
and the Dao follows the natural.

The Great Dao is *empty and void*.
*Empty and void* is without substance,
yet naturally gives birth to being.
All things under heaven,
from the myriad species to heaven and earth,
are born from the unified *qi* before the formation of yin and yang.

*Silent* means without sound,
*vast* means without form.
It stands above all things yet does not alter,
circulates through the six directions yet never ceases.
All things arise from this One—
it may be called the Mother of all under heaven.
Though it is said to have substance,
*silent* and *vast* are names without designation.

The *Laozi* says:
*"I do not know its name,
so I call it Dao and boldly name it Great."*
Extending the logic of *Great*,
one arrives at *passing*,
thus it is said: *passing away*.
Passing through the four directions and above and below,
its principle grows ever more distant,
thus it is said: *distant*.
When distant, it cannot be extended further,
so it returns to the One,
thus it is said: *returning*.

Since all things arise from this One,
the Dao is Great.
All things take form through yin and yang’s transformations,
thus heaven is Great and earth is Great.
It is also said that the Sage-King is Great—
meaning that *empty and void* is his domain,
and within this domain are the four Great ones,
while the Sage-King governs all under heaven through the Dao,
occupying one place.

Humans cultivate virtue through the Five Constants and myriad conducts,
yet they follow humility and modesty,
taking earth as their model.
Earth’s nurturing follows heaven,
heaven’s movement follows the Dao of unified *qi*,
and the Dao of unified *qi* follows the *empty and void* of nature.

Heavy is the root of light,
stillness is the master of agitation.
Thus the Sage-King never strays from his burdens,
though he enjoys splendor and comfort,
he rests in serene detachment.
How can the ruler of ten thousand chariots
consider himself lighter than the world?
Lightness will lose his ministers,
agitation will lose his rule.
Heavy is the root of light,
stillness is the master of agitation.

Speaking of governance,
the Sage-King who moves daily
does not abandon the weight of his supplies.
Though he enjoys splendor and comfort,
he depends on stillness to rest in harmony,
detached yet visible.
Light does not depart from heavy,
action does not depart from stillness,
the ruler does not depart from the people.
How can one sigh over the burdens of ruling
while holding oneself above the world?
Lightness toward the world will lose his ministers,
agitation of the people will lose his rule.

The virtuous walk without leaving tracks,
the virtuous speak without blemish,
the virtuous plan without calculation,
the virtuous close without locks yet cannot be opened,
the virtuous bind without cords yet cannot be undone.
Thus the Sage-King always practices these virtues to rescue people,
and there are none he abandons;
always practices these virtues to rescue all things,
and there are none he discards.
This is called *clinging to clarity*.

Hence, the virtuous are the teachers of the unvirtuous,
and the unvirtuous are the resources of the virtuous.
If one does not honor their teachers,
nor cherish their resources,
even if their wisdom is vast,
they are like great confusion.
This is called *essential subtlety*.

Those who walk the Dao virtuously leave no tracks—
this is called *walking without walking*,
walking, yet leaving no tracks.
Those who speak the Dao virtuously leave no flaws—
this is called *speaking without speaking*,
speaking, yet leaving no flaws.
Those who plan the Dao virtuously have no scheming thoughts,
thus they do not use calculations.
Those who close the Dao virtuously have no desires in their hearts,
so nothing can enter.
Though there are no locks or bolts,
it cannot be opened.
Those who bind the Dao virtuously understand
that the Dao is within the heart,
thus though there are no cords or constraints,
it cannot be undone.
Hence the Sage-King always uses these virtues to rescue people,
and there are none he abandons;
always uses these virtues universally to rescue all things,
and there are none he discards.
Thus, in self-benefit and benefit to others,
it is called *clinging to clarity*.
Therefore, the virtuous are the teachers of the unvirtuous,
and the unvirtuous gain from the resources of the virtuous.
Yet if one does not honor their teachers,
nor cherish their resources,
even if they are clever and resourceful,
they cling to confusion like the greatest delusion.
Without wisdom and without attainment,
this is called *essential subtlety*.

Know its masculine,
guard its feminine,
and you become the *crevice* of all under heaven.
To become the *crevice* of all under heaven,
one’s virtue never departs,
and it returns to the *baby*.
Know its white,
guard its black,
and you become the *model* of all under heaven.
To become the *model* of all under heaven,
one’s virtue is never forceful,
and it returns to the *Ultimate Void*.
Know its glory,
guard its humiliation,
and you become the *valley* of all under heaven.
To become the *valley* of all under heaven,
one’s virtue is complete,
and it returns to *primordial simplicity*.

Those who study the Dao
cannot yet fully grasp the *mindless* Dao—
they only know its masculine strength
and fail to guard its feminine softness.
The *Laozi* likens this to the *crevice* of all under heaven,
meaning to dwell low and not contend.
If one can become the *crevice* of all under heaven,
one’s virtue never strays,
and in time it returns to the *baby*.
The *baby* refers to
one who, upon seeing the world,
has no thoughts in their mind,
yet understands clearly of its own accord.
Guard its black and silent Dao,
and you may become the *model* of all under heaven.
*Model* also means
to conceal light and hide virtue.
If one can become the *model* of all under heaven,
one’s virtue is never errant,
and in time it returns to the *Ultimate Void*.

To know its glory yet not rejoice,
to guard its humiliation yet not grieve,
is like being the *empty valley* of all under heaven—
meaning to be void yet able to contain.
」

chunks.original_text: 能为天下谷，常保其德，乃具足，久则复归於朴。 朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长音掌，故大制不割。 夫朴者，大道化生一熙也，散则为阴阳。 器显形谓之器之用，四时之迁，始春而后秋，圣人观生化之有序，用之为法，宗庙则以昭穆焉，朝廷则以尊卑焉，乡党则以年齿焉，推厚德则为之官长。 是以先君后臣，先夫后妇，故体大道也之制，使人伦有序而不伤割害也。 将欲取天下而为之者，吾见其不得已。 音以天下神器，不可为也。 为者败之，执者失之。 故物或行或随，或嘘或吹，或强或羸，或载或隳。 是以圣人去甚，去奢，去泰。 上古以无为治天下，无不治矣。 至尧舜时，道德势衰，迷七义欲民从之，救衰弊之世，是将欲取治也天下而为之者也，老子曰吾见其不得已。 夫天下者，神化之器用也，而不可为也，为者败之，执者失之。 故物事也或行或随或前或后、或嘘或吹或阴或阳、或强或羸或盛或衰、或载或隳或成或败者，缘执於为。 是以圣人治天下，所以去离也下同甚、去奢、去泰者，由不执於为也。 以道佐人主者，不以兵强天下，其事好音耗还音旋。 师之所处，刑棘生焉。 大军之后，必有凶年。 故善者果而已音以下同矣，不敢以取强焉。 果而勿矜，果而勿伐，果而勿骄，果而不得已，果而勿强。 物壮则老，是谓非道，非道早已。 以用也道佐辅人主者，不以兵强取胜於天下。 夫举兵加彼，彼必应之，其事既好还报，则胜负反复矣。 夫兵者，凶器也，师师，众也。 《周官》自五人为伍，积二千五百人为师。 之所处，民事废而田不修，故荆棘生焉。 大军之后，失於耕治，必有饥岁凶年。 故善良之称用兵者果定也下同而已矣，不敢以取强焉。 果而勿自矜，果而勿克伐，果而勿生骄，果而不得已而用之，果而勿恃强。 夫物盛则衰，至理叉然。 物之用壮如兵之恃强，物壮则老，兵强则败，是谓非道。 非其道也，宜当早已止也。 夫佳兵者，不祥之器，物或恶之，故有道者不处。 是以君子居则贵左，用兵则贵右。 兵者不祥之器，非君子之器，不得已而用之，恬惔为上。 故不美也，若美必乐音落下同之，乐之者是乐杀人也。 夫乐杀人者，不可得志於天下矣。 吉事尚左，凶事尚右。 是以偏将军处左，上将军处右，言居上势，则以丧礼处之。 杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，战胜则以丧礼处之。 兵以济难，由如毒药，不可为常。 夫佳美好也兵者，不祥之器，有好胜之心而妨道德，万物或恶之，故有道者不处於佳兵。 是以君子居则贵左，左为阳，阳主生。 用兵则贵右，右为阴，阴主杀。 故知兵者，不祥之器，一非君子之器，禁暴救乱，不得已而用一之。 治国之道，恬惔安静之意为上，故一兵不可美好也，若美之者，是必乐一之驯乐之者是乐杀人也。 夫乐杀人者，人不亲之，则不可得志於天下矣。 故吉事尚左，凶事尚右，是以偏副也将军处左，古之右为尊左为卑左主生。 上将军处右，右主杀。 言居上将之势，则以丧礼处之，何谓也？ 谓杀人众多，以悲哀泣之，用战胜取强，则以丧礼处之也。 道德真经直解卷之二竟 道德真经直解卷之三
chunks.translated_text:
「能为天下谷，常保其德，乃具足，久则复归於朴。
To become the *receptive valley* of all under heaven,
ever preserving one’s virtue,
is to attain fullness—
in time it returns to the *Uncarved Block* (朴).

朴散则为器，圣人用之则为官长，音掌。
When the Uncarved Block disperses, it becomes *vessels* (器).
The sage employs it as *rulers and officials* (官长),
to govern with authority.

故大制不割。
Thus, the grandest institutions are not *severed* (割).

夫朴者，大道化生一熙也，散则为阴阳。
For the Uncarved Block is the single *radiance* (熙) of the Great Dao’s transformation,
when dispersed, it becomes *yin* and *yang*.

器显形谓之器之用，
Vessels manifest form—
this is their *application* (用).

四时之迁，始春而后秋，
The *passage* (迁) of the four seasons—
from the onset of spring to the arrival of autumn—

圣人观生化之有序，
the sage observes the ordered *generation and transformation* (生化),

用之为法，
employing it as *principles* (法),

宗庙则以昭穆焉，
in ancestral halls, through the *order of seniority* (昭穆),

朝廷则以尊卑焉，
in court, through *rank and hierarchy* (尊卑),

乡党则以年齿焉，
among villages, through *age and seniority* (年齿),

推厚德则为之官长。
promoting those of great virtue to *rulers and officials* (官长).

是以先君后臣，先夫后妇，
Hence, one honors *sovereigns before ministers* (先君后臣),
and *husbands before wives* (先夫后妇).

故体大道之制，
Thus, the *framework* (制) of the Great Dao is upheld,

使人伦有序而不伤割害也。
ensuring human relationships remain ordered
without *violence or harm* (割害).

将欲取天下而为之者，吾见其不得已。
Those who seek to *seize* all under heaven and *act* (为) upon it—
I see that they cannot help but do so.

夫天下者，神化之器用也，而不可为也。
For all under heaven is the *manifestation* (器用) of the *Divine Transformation* (神化),
yet it cannot be *artificially shaped* (为).

为者败之，执者失之。
To *shape* it (为) is to *undermine* it (败),
to *grasp* it (执) is to *lose* it (失).

故物或行或随，或嘘或吹，
Thus, things either *move forward* (行) or *follow* (随),
either *draw in* (嘘) or *push out* (吹),

或强或羸，或载或隳，
either *flourish* (强) or *wither* (羸),
either *elevate* (载) or *destroy* (隳),

或成或败者，缘执於为。
either *succeed* or *fail*—
all because one *clings to artificial shaping* (执於为).

是以圣人治天下，所以去甚、去奢、去泰者，
Hence, the sage governs all under heaven by *removing excess* (甚),
*extravagance* (奢), and *profligacy* (泰).

上古以无为治天下，无不治矣。
In the *Highest Antiquity* (上古), the sage ruled all under heaven with *non-action* (无为),
and nothing remained ungoverned.

至尧舜时，道德势衰，
By the time of Yao and Shun,
the *virtue and power* (道德) of the Dao had waned,

迷七义欲民从之，
confused by the *Seven Virtues* (七义),
they sought to *compel* (从) the people.

救衰弊之世，
To *rescue* (救) a world of *decay and exhaustion* (衰弊),

是将欲取治天下而为之者也，
this was one who sought to *seize governance* (取治) of all under heaven and *act* (为) upon it—
thus the *Laozi* says: *I see that they cannot help but do so.*

夫天下者，神化之器用也，
For all under heaven is the *manifestation* (器用) of the *Divine Transformation* (神化),

而不可为也，
yet it cannot be *artificially shaped* (为).

为者败之，执者失之。
To *shape* it (为) is to *undermine* it (败),
to *grasp* it (执) is to *lose* it (失).

故物事也或行或随或前或后，
Thus, things either *move forward* (行) or *follow* (随),
either *go before* (前) or *lag behind* (后),

或嘘或吹或阴或阳，
either *draw in* (嘘) or *push out*吹),
either *yin* (阴) or *yang* (阳),

或强或羸或盛或衰，
either *flourish* (强) or *wither* (羸),
either *prosper* (盛) or *decline* (衰),

或载或隳或成或败者，
either *elevate* (载) or *destroy* (隳),
either *succeed* or *fail*—

缘执於为。
all because one *clings to artificial shaping* (执於为).

是以圣人治天下，所以去甚、去奢、去泰者，
Hence, the sage governs all under heaven by *removing excess* (甚),
*extravagance* (奢), and *profligacy* (泰),

由不执於为也。
because they do not *cling to artificial shaping* (执於为).

以道佐人主者，
To *assist* (佐) a *ruler* (人主) with the Dao,

不以兵强天下，
one does not *coerce* (强) all under heaven with *arms* (兵),

其事好还报，
for their *endeavors* (事) will *return* (还报) as they are *reckoned* (好).

师之所处，刑棘生焉。
Wherever the *army* (师) is stationed,
*thorns and brambles* (刑棘) arise.

大军之后，必有凶年。
After a *great army* (大军),
there will surely be a *year of calamity* (凶年).

故善者果而已矣，
Thus, the *virtuous* (善) act *decisively* (果),

不敢以取强焉。
yet do not dare to *seize by force* (取强).

果而勿矜，
*Decisive* yet not *boastful* (矜),

果而勿伐，
*Decisive* yet not *self-praising* (伐),

果而勿骄，
*Decisive* yet not *arrogant* (骄),

果而不得已，
*Decisive* yet only when *there is no alternative* (不得已),

果而勿强。
*Decisive* yet not *coercive* (强).

物壮则老，
Things *flourish* (壮) yet *age* (老),

是谓非道，
this is called *not the Dao* (非道),

非道早已。
and *not the Dao* (非道) will *perish early* (早已).

以道佐辅人主者，
To *assist* (佐) and *support* (辅) a ruler with the Dao,

不以兵强取胜於天下。
one does not *coerce* (强) all under heaven with arms to *achieve victory* (取胜).

夫举兵加彼，
For to *raise arms* (举兵) and *attack* (加) another—

彼必应之，
the other will *respond* (应),

其事既好还报，
and if their *endeavors* (事) are *reckoned* (好),
then *retribution* (还报) will follow.

则胜负反复矣。
Thus, *victory and defeat* (胜负) will *alternate* (反复).

夫兵者，凶器也，
For arms are * instruments of calamity* (凶器),

师，众也。
and an *army* (师) is the *multitude* (众).

《周官》自五人为伍，
As the *Zhou Officials* (周官) states,
five people form a *unit* (伍),

积二千五百人为师。
and five hundred units make an *army* (师).

之所处，民事废而田不修，
Wherever the army is stationed,
*civil affairs* (民事) are neglected
and *fields* (田) are left *uncultivated* (不修),

故荆棘生焉。
thus *thorns and brambles* (荆棘) grow.

大军之后，失於耕治，
After a *great army* (大军),
*agriculture and governance* (耕治) are *disrupted* (失),

必有饥岁凶年。
and there will surely be *years of famine and calamity* (饥岁凶年).

故善良之称用兵者果定也而已矣，
Thus, the *virtuous and benevolent* (善良) who employ arms
do so with *resolute determination* (果定)

不敢以取强焉.
yet do not dare to *seize by force* (取强).

果而勿自矜，
*Resolute* yet not *boastful of oneself* (自矜),

果而勿克伐，
*Resolute* yet not *self-praising* (克伐),

果而勿生骄，
*Resolute* yet not *arrogant* (生骄),

果而不得已而用之，
*Resolute* yet only when *there is no alternative* (不得已),

果而勿恃强.
*Resolute* yet not *relying on force* (恃强).

夫物盛则衰，
For when things *prosper* (盛),

至理叉然。
the *ultimate principle* (至理) is *thus* (叉然).

物之用壮如兵之恃强，
The *application* (用) of things when *flourishing* (壮),
such as arms *relying on force* (兵之恃强),

物壮则老，
things *flourish* yet *age* (壮则老),

兵强则败，
and armies *flourish in force* yet *meet defeat* (强则败),

是谓非道。
this is called *not the Dao* (非道).

非其道也，
Not being the Dao,

宜当早已止也.
it is *proper* (宜) to *halt early* (早已止).

夫佳兵者，不祥之器，
For *good arms* (佳兵) are *inauspicious instruments* (不祥之器),

物或恶之，
things may *abhor* them (恶),

故有道者不处.
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not *employ* them (处).

是以君子居则贵左，
Hence, the *virtuous* (君子) value the *left* (左) when at home,

用兵则贵右.
and value the *right* (右) when employing arms.

兵者不祥之器，
Arms are *inauspicious instruments* (不祥之器),

非君子之器，
not the *tools* (器) of the virtuous.

不得已而用之，
they are used only when *there is no alternative* (不得已),

恬惔为上.
and *tranquility and contentment* (恬惔) are the highest virtues.

故不美也，
Thus, they are not *beautified* (美),

若美必乐，
if *beautified* (美), then there will be *delight* (乐),

乐之者是乐杀人也.
and those who *delight* in them are *delighting in killing* (乐杀人).

夫乐杀人者，
For those who *delight in killing* (乐杀人),

不可得志於天下矣.
cannot *fulfill their ambitions* (得志) in all under heaven.

吉事尚左，
*Auspicious matters* (吉事) are valued on the *left* (尚左),

凶事尚右.
and *inauspicious matters* (凶事) on the *right* (尚右).

是以偏将军处左，
Thus, the *assistant general* (偏将军) is stationed on the *left* (左),

上将军处右，
and the *commander-in-chief* (上将军) on the *right* (右).

言居上将之势，
Speaking of the *position* (势) of the *commander-in-chief* (上将),

则以丧礼处之。
it is treated with *funeral rites* (丧礼).

杀人众多，
For *killing many* (杀人众多),

以悲哀泣之，
is *wept with sorrow* (悲哀泣),

战胜则以丧礼处之.
and *victory in battle* is treated with *funeral rites* (丧礼).

兵以济难，
Arms are used to *resolve crises* (济难),

由如毒药，
like *poisonous medicine*—

不可为常.
they cannot be *employed as a norm* (为常).

夫佳美好兵者，
For those who *cherish fine arms* (佳美好兵),

不祥之器，
they are *inauspicious instruments* (不祥之器),

有好胜之心而妨道德，
with a *desire for victory* (好胜),
which *hinders virtue and power* (妨道德),

万物或恶之，
all things may *abhor* them (恶),

故有道者不处於佳兵.
Thus, those who follow the Dao do not *employ fine arms* (佳兵).

是以君子居则贵左，
Hence, the *virtuous* (君子) value the *left* (左) when at home,

左为阳，
the *left* (左) is *yang*—

阳主生.
*yang* governs *life and generation* (主生).

用兵则贵右，
And when employing arms,
they value the *right* (右),

右为阴，
the *right* (右) is *yin*—

阴主杀.
*yin* governs *destruction and death* (主杀).

故知兵者，
Thus, those who *know arms* (知兵),

不祥之器，
*inauspicious instruments* (不祥之器),

一非君子之器，
indeed are not the *tools* (器) of the virtuous,

禁暴救乱，
used only to *restrain tyranny* (禁暴) and *relieve chaos* (救乱),

不得已而用之一.
when *there is no alternative* (不得已).

治国之道，
The *Dao of governing a state* (治国之道),

恬惔安静之意为上，
values *tranquility and contentment* (恬惔) and *peaceful repose* (安静),

故一兵不可美好也，
thus, arms cannot be *beautified* (美好),

若美之者，
if one *beautifies* them (美),

是必乐之一驯，
then they will surely *delight in* them (乐),

乐之者是乐杀人也.
and those who *delight* in them are *delighting in killing* (乐杀人).

夫乐杀人者，
For those who *delight in killing* (乐杀人),

人不亲之，
people will not *hold them dear* (亲),

则不可得志於天下矣.
and thus they cannot *fulfill their ambitions* (得志) in all under heaven.

故吉事尚左，
Thus, *auspicious matters* (吉事) are valued on the *left* (尚左),

凶事尚右，
and *inauspicious matters* (凶事) on the *right* (尚右).

是以偏副将军处左，
Hence, the *assistant general* (偏副将军) is stationed on the *left* (左),

古之右为尊，
in antiquity, the *right* (右) was honored (尊),

左为卑，
and the *left* (左) was lowly (卑),

左主生.
the *left* governs *life and generation* (主生).

上将军处右，
The *commander-in-chief* (上将军) is stationed on the *right* (右),

右主杀.
the *right* governs *destruction and death* (主杀).

言居上将之势，
Speaking of the *position* (势) of the *commander-in-chief* (上将),

则以丧礼处之，
it is treated with *funeral rites* (

chunks.original_text: 本来子邵若愚直解 清河居士张知新校正 道常无名，朴虽小，天下莫能臣。 侯王若能守，万物将自宾。 天地相合，以降甘露，人莫之令音零而自均。 始制有名，名亦既有。 夫亦将知止，知止所以不殆。 大道虚无而常无名，自元始化一气。 一气者，有而未形，丰之曰朴。 其朴比大道虽小，然为万物母，故天下莫能臣下也。 侯王若能守其朴，万物将自宾伏也。 以一治天下，譬如天地之气相合，以降甘雨，润露普徧，人莫之令而自均。 大道因朴始立制而有名，名亦既有，夫亦将知止。 若不止则散失其朴，知止所以不殆而可长久。 譬道之在天下，由川谷之与江海也。 知人者智，自知者明。 胜人者有力，自胜者强。 知足者富，强行者有志。 失其所止者久，死而不亡者寿。 譬道之在天下，由如也川谷之水皆与归於江海也，喻天下万事，总归於道。 夫视其所以，观其所由，察其所安，知人者不过用智，人皆以智为明，不如反智於内而自知，自知自理者是谓明。 胜人者不过有刚强谋略、丰财锐势为力，不如息力修心，万境不动而自胜，自胜者是谓强。 世以财厚为富，虽厚有尽，但知自心本来具足，用无穷尽者，是谓富。 世间所学皆小志，惟强行於道者，谓之有志。 孔子志於道。 从事皆合於道，是故不失其所止者，乃能久。 形虽死而性不亡迷也失也，处於不生灭之乡，万劫常脊者，是谓寿。 大道泛兮，其可左右。 万物恃之以生而不辞，功成不居，衣被万物而不为主。 故常无欲，可名於小矣； 万物归焉而不知主，可名於大矣。 是以圣人能成其大也，以其不自大，故能成其大。 执大象，天下往。 往而不害，安平。 大道泛兮，言无定位也，谓可大可小，故其可左右。 何谓可小？ 夫道，万物恃之以生而不辞，谓如春功用备成，至夏则春意不居。 当春之时，万物衣被而不为主宰，故道常无欲於物，则可名於小矣。 何谓可大？ 夫万物总归於道焉而不知主，可名於大矣。 是以圣人能成其大也，而效其道为而不恃，功成不居，以其不自为大之迹，故能成就其大。 执此大象以治，天下无不归往。 民往之者，缘往而不害故也，所以天下安平泰。 乐音岳与饵，过客止。 道之出口，淡乎其无味。 视之不足见，听之不足闻，用之不可既。 世俗殢五音之乐与饮食之饵，百年之间如待过客止。 道之出口，淡乎其无味，然而视之不足见，听之不足闻，使之治国、治家、治身，至於生之前、死之后，用之不可既。 尽也 将欲歙音吸之，必固张之；
chunks.translated_text:
The **Dao** is originally nameless.
Though **primordial simplicity** (*pu*) is small,
nothing under heaven can subdue it.

If lords and kings could guard it,
all things would submit of their own accord.

When Heaven and Earth unite,
they descend sweet dew—
no one commands it,
yet all is evenly nourished.

At first, **institutions** were established,
and names were given.
But one must also know when to stop—
knowing when to stop is how one avoids ruin.

The **Great Dao** is empty and formless,
yet eternally nameless.
From **Primordial Oneness** (*yuan shi*), it transforms into **One Qi** (*yi qi*).
This **One Qi**—
existing yet unformed—
is called **primordial simplicity** (*pu*).
Though **primordial simplicity** is small compared to the **Great Dao**,
it is the mother of all things,
and thus nothing under heaven can subdue it.

If lords and kings could guard their **primordial simplicity**,
all things would submit and bow.

To govern the world with **Oneness**,
it is like Heaven and Earth’s qi uniting,
descending sweet rain and dew,
spreading universally—
no one commands it,
yet all is evenly nourished.

The **Great Dao**, through **primordial simplicity**, first established institutions and gave names.
Names having been given,
one must also know when to stop.
If one does not stop,
one will lose their **primordial simplicity**.
Knowing when to stop
is how one avoids ruin and endures.

The **Dao** in the world
is like rivers and valleys flowing toward the sea.
To know others is wisdom,
but to know oneself is enlightenment.
To overcome others is strength,
but to overcome oneself is power.
To know contentment is wealth,
but to act with resolve is to have purpose.
To lose one’s proper place is to perish early,
but to die without losing one’s nature is longevity.

The **Dao** in the world
is like rivers and valleys—
all waters flow toward the sea.
This illustrates how all things under heaven
ultimately return to the **Dao**.

To observe its methods,
to examine its path,
to discern its rest—
those who know others do so through wisdom,
but people mistake wisdom for enlightenment.
Instead, one should turn wisdom inward
and know oneself.
To know oneself and govern oneself—
this is called enlightenment.

To overcome others is to rely on strength,
strategy, wealth, and sharp influence—
but this is not true power.
Instead, one should still the force,
cultivate the heart,
and remain unmoved by all circumstances—
this is called power.

The world considers wealth as riches,
yet riches are finite.
But if one knows the heart’s original sufficiency—
its inexhaustible use—
this is called true wealth.

Worldly pursuits are all small ambitions,
but to act resolutely in the **Dao**
is to have true purpose.
Confucius had purpose in the **Dao**.

All actions aligned with the **Dao**
are thus enduring.
Though the body may die,
the nature does not perish.
To dwell in the realm of non-birth-and-death,
enduring through countless kalpas—
this is called longevity.

The **Great Dao** is vast,
and may be turned left or right.
All things depend on it for life,
yet it does not claim them.
When its work is done, it does not dwell on it.
It clothes all things yet does not rule them.
Thus, it is always without desire—
it may be called *small*.
All things return to it,
yet it does not know itself as master—
it may be called *great*.
Therefore, the sage can accomplish the great
because they do not consider themselves great.

Hold fast to this **Great Image**,
and all under heaven will come.
They come without harm,
and the world is at peace.

The **Great Dao** is vast—
it has no fixed position,
for it may be great or small,
and thus may be turned left or right.

What is meant by *small*?
The **Dao**—
all things depend on it for life,
yet it does not claim them.
Like spring’s work fully realized,
by summer, spring’s influence has faded.
In spring, all things are nourished,
yet it does not rule them.
Thus, the **Dao** is always without desire for things—
it may be called *small*.

What is meant by *great*?
All things return to the **Dao**,
yet it does not know itself as master—
it may be called *great*.
Therefore, the sage can accomplish the great
because they do not trace their actions to themselves.
Their work done, they do not dwell on it.
Because they do not claim greatness,
they achieve true greatness.

Hold this **Great Image** to govern,
and all under heaven will come.
The people come because they come without harm—
thus the world is at peace and harmonious.

Music and food are like bait for passing guests.
When the **Dao** is spoken of,
it is bland, without taste.
To see it, it is insufficient;
to hear it, it is inaudible.
To use it, it is inexhaustible.

The world indulges in the five tones of music
and the allurements of food,
yet in a hundred years, it is like waiting for a passing guest to stop.

When the **Dao** is spoken of,
it is bland, without taste.
Yet to see it, it is insufficient;
to hear it, it is inaudible.
To apply it in governing the state,
the family,
the self—
before birth, after death—
its use is inexhaustible.

If one would draw in the breath,
one must first exhale fully;
---

chunks.original_text: 将欲弱之，必固强之； 将欲废之，必固兴之； 将欲夺之，必固与之。 是谓微明。 柔之胜刚，弱之胜强。 鱼不可脱於渊，国之利器，不可以示人。 将欲歙敛也之，必固张之； 将欲弱之，必固强之； 将欲废之，必固兴之； 将欲夺之，必固与之。 阴根於阳，此必然之理。 识事之理者，是谓微明，故知柔之胜刚，弱之胜强也。 夫鱼不可脱离也於渊水也，如国之利器用也，不可以示明也人。 若示人，则如鱼离水。 设符玺表信，制斗秤令平，此便国之利用，将欲救弊，必固转生不淳，盖不察微明之义。 道常无为而无不为，侯王若能守，万物将自化。 化而欲作，吾将镇以无名之朴。 无名之朴，亦将不欲。 不欲以静，天下将自正。 治天下之道，常处事於无为，而天下无不为治也。 侯王若能守无为，万物将自化。 化而有欲作起也者，吾将镇安也以无名之朴。 无名之朴者，亦将不欲是也。 不欲则以静，所以天下民心将自正。 上德不德，是以有德； 下德不失德，是以无德。 上德无为而无以为，下德为之而有以为。 上仁为之而无以为，上义为之而有以为。 上礼为之而莫之应，则攘臂而仍之。 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。 夫礼者，忠信之薄而乱之首也。 前识者，道之华而愚之始也。 是以大丈夫处其厚不处其薄，居其实不居其华，故去彼取此。 太古之时，上德不显其德，是以有德。 至伏羲之时，造书契，定婚姻之类，因显其德，而为下德。 然虽不失德，因有为德之迹，是以无德。 夫上德者，用无为之治而无以为事。 下德，用有为之教而有以为事也。 至尧舜之时，上以仁爱人利物曰仁人之德为之治，化而无以为事。 其次至三王，上生可否之义，分别为之而是有以为也。 其次至五霸，上体事之礼而为之治，何期礼出诈生，而民莫之应，用礼立法，欲人惧刑而从仁义，如是则攘以手御臂也臂而使民仍就也之。 放因失道而后用德，失德而后用七，失也而后用义，失义而后用礼。 夫礼者，救世之法而以信为本，缘忠信之薄而为乱之首始也也。 如前代显智识治世者，乃道之华，非道之实，因徇其华而愚民之始也。 是以大丈夫处其忠信之厚，不处其忠信之薄，居其道之实，不居其道之华，故去彼华薄，取此实厚。 昔之得一者，天得一以清，地得一以宁，神得一以灵，谷得一以盈，万物得一以生，侯王得一以为天下正。 其致之一也，天无以清将恐裂，地无以宁将恐发，神无以灵将恐歇，谷无以盈将恐竭，万物无以生将恐灭，侯王无以为正而贵高将恐蹶。 故贵以贱为本，高以下为基。 是以侯王自称孤寡不谷，此其以贱为本耶？ 非乎？ 故致数誉无誉，不欲琭琭如玉，珞珞如石。 夫一者，万物之母也，万物皆自一生，故得一则昌，失一则亡。 老子言昔之得一者，天得一以为也下同清而覆，地得一以宁而载，人之神得一以灵，神显用曰灵三才之间、四方上下为谷，得一以盈，满也万物得一以生矣，侯王理世，得一为法以为天下正。 其各致之一也，若天无失也下同一以清将恐拆裂，地无一以宁将恐发泄，水火风伏下神无一以灵将恐其神歇，散也谷无一以一盈将恐宇宙竭，尽也万物无一以生将恐生化灭，侯王无一以为正，而恃我之贵高，失於恭谦，将恐其位蹶。
chunks.translated_text:
The one who would weaken it must first strengthen it;
The one who would discard it must first exalt it;
The one who would take from it must first give to it.
This is called **subtle luminosity**.

The yielding overcomes the rigid;
The weak overcomes the strong.

Fish cannot be lifted from the depths;
The state’s sharpest tools
should not be displayed to the people.

The one who would gather must first disperse;
The one who would weaken must first strengthen;
The one who would discard must first exalt;
The one who would take must first give.

Yin takes root in yang—
this is the inevitable order.

Those who grasp the logic of things
are said to possess **subtle luminosity**,
and thus know that yielding overcomes rigidity,
that weakness overcomes strength.

Fish cannot be separated from the depths—
just as the state’s sharpest tools,
once revealed, are like fish out of water.

When seals and decrees are issued,
when measures and scales are standardized,
these are the state’s useful tools.
Yet if one seeks to remedy flaws,
one must first allow corruption to flourish,
for failing to perceive the principle of **subtle luminosity**.

The **Dao** acts without action yet nothing remains undone.
If lords and kings could uphold it,
all things would transform of their own accord.

When transformation stirs to action,
I shall govern it with the **nameless Primordial**.
The **nameless Primordial** also desires nothing.

Without desire, all things settle—
and the world will align itself.

To govern the world,
one must act without acting,
and yet nothing will remain ungoverned.

If lords and kings could uphold non-action,
all things would transform of their own accord.
But if transformation gives rise to restless desire,
I shall steady it with the **nameless Primordial**.
The **nameless Primordial** also desires nothing.

Without desire, all things grow still—
and the hearts of the people will align themselves.

The highest virtue does not cling to virtue,
and thus has virtue.
The lower virtue does not lose virtue,
and thus lacks virtue.

The highest virtue acts without acting,
the lower virtue acts with effort.
The highest benevolence acts without effort,
the highest righteousness acts with effort.
The highest propriety acts with effort,
yet when none respond,
it resorts to force and compulsion.

Thus, when the **Dao** is lost, virtue arises;
when virtue is lost, benevolence arises;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
when righteousness is lost, propriety arises.

For propriety is the thinning of sincerity and trust—
the beginning of chaos.

Premature wisdom is the flourish of the **Dao**,
the start of folly.

Thus, the superior person dwells in its depth,
not its shallowness;
in its reality,
not its flourish.
Hence, they discard the latter and embrace the former.

In the age of antiquity,
the highest virtue did not display its virtue,
and thus had virtue.
By the time of Fu Xi,
writing and marriage laws were established,
and virtue was made manifest—
thus becoming lower virtue.
Though it did not lose virtue,
it bore the traces of deliberate action,
and thus lacked virtue.

The highest virtue governs through non-action,
the lower virtue governs through deliberate teaching.
In the age of Yao and Shun,
the highest virtue loved people and benefited all,
acting as a benevolent ruler without effort.
In the age of the Three Kings,
the highest virtue established right and wrong,
distinguishing and acting—
thus with effort.
In the age of the Five Hegemons,
the highest virtue upheld ritual propriety in governance,
yet when ritual produced deceit and the people did not respond,
laws were enacted to make them fear punishment
and follow righteousness—
thus resorting to force and compulsion.

Thus, when the **Dao** is lost, virtue arises;
when virtue is lost, benevolence arises;
when benevolence is lost, righteousness arises;
when righteousness is lost, propriety arises.

For propriety is a method to save the world,
rooted in sincerity,
yet arising from the thinning of trust—
the origin of chaos.

Those who prematurely display wisdom
are but the flourish of the **Dao**,
not its substance,
and thus their adherence to its flourish
marks the beginning of folly among the people.

Hence, the superior person dwells in the depth of sincerity,
not its shallowness;
in the reality of the **Dao**,
not its flourish.
Thus, they discard the shallow and the flourish,
and embrace the deep and the real.

In ancient times, those who attained **Oneness**—
Heaven attained **Oneness** and became clear,
Earth attained **Oneness** and became tranquil,
The spirit attained **Oneness** and became responsive,
The valleys attained **Oneness** and became full,
All things attained **Oneness** and flourished,
And the lords and kings attained **Oneness**
to govern the world aright.

Yet if **Oneness** were lost—
Heaven, without **Oneness**, would fear fracturing,
Earth, without **Oneness**, would fear upheaval,
The spirit, without **Oneness**, would fear stagnation,
The valleys, without **Oneness**, would fear exhaustion,
All things, without **Oneness**, would fear extinction,
And lords and kings, without **Oneness**,
relying on their noble height,
would fear their position toppling.

Thus, nobility finds its foundation in humility,
and height finds its base in lowliness.
Hence, lords and kings call themselves "lonely, few, and unworthy"—
is this not their grounding in humility?
Is it not so?

Thus, true praise is without praise,
not like jade clinking or stone clattering.
**Oneness** is the mother of all things;
all things arise from **Oneness**.
Thus, to attain **Oneness** is to flourish,
to lose **Oneness** is to perish.

The **Laozi** speaks:
In ancient times, those who attained **Oneness**—
Heaven attained **Oneness** and became clear, covering all;
Earth attained **Oneness** and became tranquil, bearing all;
The human spirit attained **Oneness** and became responsive;
The valleys attained **Oneness** and became full;
All things attained **Oneness** and flourished;
And lords and kings, attaining **Oneness**,
governed the world aright.

Yet if **Oneness** were lost—
Heaven, without **Oneness**, would fear shattering,
Earth, without **Oneness**, would fear eruption,
The spirit, without **Oneness**, would fear fading,
The valleys, without **Oneness**, would fear depletion,
All things, without **Oneness**, would fear annihilation,
And lords and kings, without **Oneness**,
relying on their noble height,
losing reverence and humility,
would fear their position collapsing.

chunks.original_text: 失也故处於贵者，以贱为本； 处於高者，以下为基。 是以侯王自称孤小失父曰孤寡女无夫曰寡不谷者，以其就下。 此其以贱为本耶？ 非乎？ 将认我之贵高，故致数不一也誉。 褒誉誉者毁之，基不若无誉，故不欲琭琭如玉之誉者，不政珞珞如石之毁也。 反者道之动，弱者道之用。 天下之物生於有，有生於无。 驰心於外者，不若反心於内，故反者乃道之动。 动而反归无心曰弱，弱者乃道之用也。 世人只知天下之物生於有，不知有本生於无，故知无者道之用也。 上士闻道，勤而行之； 中士闻道，若存若亡； 下士闻道，大笑之，不笑不足以为道。 上士学也下同闻道，能生实信，动而行之，故云上士。 中士闻道，胸中无主，若存若亡，故云中士。 下士闻道，尘重业深，闻说其心，不依一法，兀然无事，具足道德，必大笑之。 下士闻而不笑者，必是奇怪矫妄，有为法术，此不足以为道。 故建言有之：明道若昧，夷道若类，音耒进道若退，上德若谷，太白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质真若渝，大方无隅，大器晚成，大音希声，大象无形，道隐无名。 故建立也言有之：老子引先圣之语也。 明道若昧，悟道无得，故若昏昧。 夷平也道若类，大道平夷，无修无证，故若类。 进道若退，不用心智，故若退。 上德若谷，心如大虚，能容万境，故若谷。 大白若辱，无为而为，故若辱。 广德若不足，大德之士，圆修万行，故若不足。 建德若偷，行行无迹，故若 偷。 质真若渝，渝，变也。 自心清静，随物安委，故若渝。 大方无隅，淫房酒肆，皆成道场，故无隅。 大器晚成，勤诚历修，方能究竟。 大音希声，至乐自闻。 已上十一句，言大象无形，由道隐无名之谓也。 夫惟道，善贷音太且成。 道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物。 万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和。 夫惟道，善贷假借曰贷与阴阳生化而且成，终复归道。 自道生一气，一气分而生二仪，二仪生化，以一气为主，以一合二，故云三。 一气在阴阳之中，故名冲气。 以三能生万物，故万物无不负背也阴而抱向也阳，皆仗冲气以为和和者生之本。 人之所恶，惟孤寡不谷，而王公以为称，故物或损之而益，益之而损。 人之所教，我亦义教之。 强梁者，不得其死，吾将以为教父。 人之所恶，惟孤寡不谷，而王公以为称者，何也？ 理世之道，以谦下为法，故物或损之者而受益，益之者而见损，故知谦者受益，此古人之所教也。 老子曰我亦以谦为义而教之，夫何故？ 见恃强梁者不得尽其理而死。 老子曰吾将谦道，以此为父教。 天下之至柔，驰骋天下之至坚，无有入於无间。 音涧是以知无为之有益也。 不言之教，无为之益，天下希及之矣。 天下之至柔者，无心之心，又玄是也。 人能驰骋至柔，此天下之至坚而不坏者。 古颂云：不见头也无手，世界壤时终不朽。 以无为有，故曰无为入於不生灭之乡，万劫长存，更无间断，是以知无为之有益也。 此不可言及之教，老子叹曰：无为之益，天下希及之矣。 名与身孰亲？ 身与货孰多？ 得与亡孰病？ 是故甚爱必大费，多藏必厚亡。 知足不辱，知止不殆，可以长久。 高名与身，二者孰亲？ 身与财货，二者孰多？ 因名利而生得与亡，失也孰病？
chunks.translated_text:
The noble, though in high estate, takes humility as root;
The exalted, though in lofty place, takes lowliness as foundation.
Thus do lords and kings—
Calling themselves "orphaned" when fatherless,
"widowed" when husbandless,
"without grain" when lacking sustenance—
All to descend to the lowly.
Is this not taking humility as root?
Or is it that, recognizing their noble height,
They thus invite the loss of **Oneness** through excessive praise?

Praise, when excessive, becomes blame;
A foundation without praise is better.
Thus, one does not seek the **tinkling** of jade-like praise,
Nor the **clattering** of stone-like censure.

The **Dao** moves through inversion;
The **weak** is the **Dao**’s operation.
All things arise from **Being**, yet **Being** arises from **Non-Being**.
He who gallops his mind outward
Finds nothing compared to turning it inward—
Thus, inversion is the **Dao**’s motion.

Motion, when returned to **Non-Being**, is called **weak**—
The **weak** is the **Dao**’s operation.

The world knows only that all things arise from **Being**,
Yet does not know that **Being** arises from **Non-Being**—
Thus, the **Non-Being** is the **Dao**’s operation.

The **Superior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Diligently practices it;
The **Middle Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Holds it as if it exists, as if it does not;
The **Inferior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Laughs at it—
And if he does not laugh, it is not the **Dao**.

The **Superior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Generates true faith and acts upon it—
Thus he is called **Superior**.
The **Middle Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Has no resolve within—
Holding it as if it exists, as if it does not—
Thus he is called **Middle**.
The **Inferior Man**, hearing the **Dao**,
Burdened by dust and deep in deeds,
Hearing its teaching, does not adhere to any single principle,
Yet, full of virtue and **power**,
He laughs at it.
The **Inferior Man** who does not laugh at the **Dao**
Must be clinging to strange, contrived, artificial methods—
This is not the **Dao**.

Thus it is said:
The **Dao**, though bright, seems dim;
The **Dao**, though smooth, seems rough;
Advancing the **Dao** seems like retreat;
**Virtue** at its height seems like a valley;
Great **whiteness** seems like shame;
Ample **virtue** seems insufficient;
Established **virtue** seems like theft;
True **simplicity** seems corrupt;
The greatest **rectitude** has no corners;
The greatest vessel is fashioned last;
The greatest music is without sound;
The greatest form is without shape—
The **Dao** is hidden, nameless.

Thus it is said:
The **Dao**, though bright, seems dim—
For enlightenment brings no gain, thus it seems obscured.
The **Dao**, though smooth, seems rough—
For the great **Way** is plain and unadorned, requiring no cultivation or proof.
Advancing the **Dao** seems like retreat—
For it requires no contrivance of the mind.
**Virtue** at its height seems like a valley—
For the heart, vast as emptiness, contains all things.
Great **whiteness** seems like shame—
For action without effort appears as disgrace.
Ample **virtue** seems insufficient—
For the virtuous, perfect in all deeds, yet appear lacking.
Established **virtue** seems like theft—
For its actions leave no trace.
True **simplicity** seems corrupt—
*Semü*—change. The mind, serene and still,
Adapts to all things without resistance—
Thus it seems transformed.
The greatest **rectitude** has no corners—
For brothels and taverns become **Dao**’s sanctuaries.
The greatest vessel is fashioned last—
For only through diligent, sincere practice does one attain fulfillment.
The greatest music is without sound—
For supreme harmony is self-evident.
The above eleven lines speak of the **Dao**’s hidden, nameless nature—
Thus, the **Dao** is formless, beyond name.

Only the **Dao**,
Lends itself to **sound** and **completion**.
The **Dao** generates **Oneness**,
**Oneness** generates **Twoness**,
**Twoness** generates **Threeness**,
**Threeness** generates all things.
All things bear **yin** while embracing **yang**,
And through **suong-qi** achieve harmony.
Only the **Dao**,
Lends itself to **borrowing**—*dài*—
**Yin** and **yang** generate and transform,
Yet ultimately return to the **Dao**.
From the **Dao** arises **One Qi**,
**One Qi** divides to form **Two Principles**,
**Two Principles** generate and transform,
With **One Qi** as master,
**One** merging with **Two**—
Thus **Threeness**.
**One Qi** dwells within **yin** and **yang**,
Hence called **suong-qi**.
Through **Threeness**, all things arise—
Thus all things bear **yin** on their backs
And embrace **yang** toward their fronts,
All relying on **suong-qi** for harmony—
Harmony is the root of life.

What men detest—
Orphaned, widowed, without grain—
Yet kings and lords adopt as titles,
Thus things may be lost to gain,
Or gained to lose.
What men teach,
I also teach as **right**.
The **strong and violent** do not meet a natural end—
I shall take this as my lesson.

Why do men detest orphaned, widowed, without grain,
Yet kings and lords adopt such titles?
The **Way** of governing the world
Takes humility as law—
Thus things may be lost to gain,
Or gained to lose,
And one knows that the humble receive benefit—
This was the teaching of the ancients.

The **Master** said:
I too teach humility as **right**—
Why?
For those who rely on strength and violence
Do not fulfill their governance and perish.

The **Master** said:
I shall teach the **Way** of humility,
Taking this as my father’s lesson.

The **softest** in the world
Overcomes the **hardest** in the world—
Nothing enters where there are no gaps.
Thus one knows the benefit of **Non-Action**.

The teaching of **Non-Speech**,
The benefit of **Non-Action**—
Few in the world attain it.

The **softest** in the world
Is the **heart without heart**—
Yet deeper still is **Xuan**.
If one can wield this **softness**,
It becomes the **hardest** in the world—
Unbreakable.

The ancient hymn says:
*"No head to see, no hands to hold—*
*When the world’s foundation is laid, it knows no decay."*
Through **Non-Being** as **Being**,
One enters the realm of **Non-Birth-and-Death**,
Eternally enduring, without interruption—
Thus one knows the benefit of **Non-Action**.
This is a teaching beyond words—
The **Master** sighed:
The benefit of **Non-Action**—
Few in the world attain it.

Which is more intimate—**name** or **body**?
Which is more abundant—**body** or **wealth**?
Which brings greater harm—**gain** or **loss**?
Thus, the more one loves excessively, the greater the expenditure;
The more one hoards, the greater the loss.
Knowing sufficiency brings no shame;
Knowing when to stop brings no peril—
Thus one may endure.

Which is more intimate—**high name** or **body**?
Which is more abundant—**body** or **wealth**?
Gain and loss arise from **name** and **profit—**
Which brings greater harm?

chunks.original_text: 是故甚爱名者，必因名大则费； 损也多藏货者，必因货厚而亡。 失也居名知足则不辱，居货知止则不殆危也，可以长久。 大成若缺，其用不敝。 大盈若冲，其用不穷。 大直若屈，大巧若拙，大辩若讷。 躁胜寒，静胜热，清静为天下正。 大成者，反若如也下同缺不完也，故其用不敝。 败也大盈满也者反若冲虚也，故其用不穷尽也。 大直者不申反若屈，大巧者藏智反若拙，大辫者不言反若讷。 是以缺能胜成，虚能胜满，屈能胜直。 拙胜巧，讷胜辩，如躁胜寒阳动则躁，静胜热阴止则静。 此者如药对病，惟清静无为能空万境而绝对治，乃为天下正。 天下有道，却走马以粪； 天下无道，戎马生於郊。 罪莫大於可欲，祸莫大於不知足，咎莫大於欲得。 故知足之足，常足矣。 古之兵即农也，农即兵也，有事则征，无事则耕。 天下有道，民各安业，却退也走马，战士以粪田畴，修治农事。 天下无亡也道，兵戎之马孳生於郊，离王城三十里为近郊，六十里为远郊。 亡道之由。 罪莫大於纵心可欲，祸莫大於食心不知止足，咎莫大於专心欲得。 夫罪祸咎皆因欲起，若心无欲，故能知足，其心之足，所遇而常足矣，祸咎自除，何罪之有？ 不出户，知天下； 不窥牖，见天道。

Thus, the one who loves **name** excessively will inevitably incur great costs when **name** grows vast;
The one who hoards **wealth** will surely suffer great loss when **wealth** becomes abundant.
To dwell in **name** yet know sufficiency brings no shame,
To dwell in **wealth** yet know when to stop brings no peril—
Thus one may endure.

The great completion seems incomplete,
Yet its use is never exhausted.
The great fullness seems empty,
Yet its use is never depleted.
The great uprightness seems crooked,
The great cleverness seems clumsy,
The great eloquence seems tongue-tied.

**Yang** overcomes **cold** (by its vigor),
**Yin** overcomes **heat** (by its stillness),
**Qingjing** (purity and tranquility) is the **Dao** of the world.

Great completion is like inversion—
Thus it seems as if it were not fully realized,
Yet its use is never exhausted.
**Defeat** is like great fullness—
Thus it seems as if it were empty,
Yet its use is never depleted.

Great uprightness does not assert itself—
Thus it seems like crookedness;
Great cleverness conceals its wisdom—
Thus it seems like clumsiness;
Great eloquence does not speak—
Thus it seems like tongue-tiedness.

Hence, incompleteness can overcome completion,
emptiness can overcome fullness,
crookedness can overcome uprightness.
Clumsiness overcomes cleverness,
tongue-tiedness overcomes eloquence—
Just as **Yang** overcomes **cold** (when active),
**Yin** overcomes **heat** (when still).
This is like medicine countering illness,
and only **purity, tranquility, and Non-Action** can void all **realms** and achieve absolute cure—
Thus it is the **Dao** of the world.

When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
warhorses are turned back to till the fields;
When the **Dao** is absent from the world,
warhorses breed in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than **desire** for what is **obtainable**,
No calamity is greater than **greed** for what is **unknowable**,
No fault is greater than **covetousness** for what is **acquired**.

Hence, one who truly knows sufficiency is always sufficient.
The ancient **army** was the **peasantry**,
And the **peasantry** was the **army**—
When there was conflict, they fought;
When there was peace, they cultivated.
When the **Dao** prevails in the world,
the people each settle into their occupations,
and warhorses are turned back to till the fields.
Soldiers use their **excrement** to fertilize the fields,
and they attend to agricultural matters.

When the **Dao** is absent from the world,
warhorses multiply in the suburbs—
Thirty **li** from the royal **city** is the near suburb,
Sixty **li** from the royal **city** is the far suburb.
The cause of the absence of the **Dao** is this:

No crime is greater than indulging the **heart** in **desire** for what is **obtainable**,
No calamity is greater than gluttony of the **heart** in **unknowing** sufficiency,
No fault is greater than fixating the **heart** on **covetousness** for what is **acquired**.

Indeed, crimes, calamities, and faults all arise from **desire**.
If the **heart** is without **desire**,
Then one can know sufficiency—
Its sufficiency is always sufficient,
Whatever it encounters.
Calamities and faults are thus removed—
What crimes can there be?

Without stepping outside the door,
One knows the world;
Without peering through the window,
One sees the **Dao** of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 其出弥远，其知弥少。 是以圣人不行而知，不见而名，不为而成。 夫道均化於万物，而知道在我矣。 欲见道者，不须出户，但推照一心，其一与万物一皆同，故能知天下万物也。 若更能弃推照之迹，心无系着，则不须窥牖，向外视也而见天之道也。 若向外求之於算数，求之於阴阳，求之於人事，其出弥远，则其知弥少矣。 是以圣人不行而知万物之性，不见而名天之所造者，而在不无也为而成。 为学日益，为道日损。 损之又损，以至无为，无为而无不为矣。 故取天下者，常以无事，及其有事，不足以取天下。 为学者日务滋益是也，为道者日损万缘是也。 夫为学务益者有二病：一者读诵抄写，持事多闻，名着事。 二者寻於书义，穷究文理，名着理。 此皆心有所着，故当损之。 夫为道务损者，亦有二病：一者断除妄想，心外求静，名执无。 二者并去尘缘，专守一心，名执有。 此皆心有所执，宜又损之。 损去为学为道之心，离着离执，以至无为之道。 无为者，是无心而为也。 无心非灭无也，谓无一切心，名曰无心。 无心而为，自然境空，任其耳目而视听，自除从其贫富好丑，自灭运水般柴役，游於世而无所累，故无为而无不为用矣。 故以道取治也天下者，常以无事，及其有事，不足以取治也天下。 圣人无常心，以百姓心为心。 善者吾善之，不善者吾亦善之，德善矣。 信者吾信之，不信者吾亦信之，德信矣。 圣人之在天下，惵惵为音谓天下浑心。 百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆孩之。 圣人无欲无为，无常处之心，以百姓之心应事而为心，《击辞》云：寂然不动，感而遂通天下之故。 因事显心而见其德。 善者吾善之，有不善者，圣人不分别，吾亦善之，因亦善之，德化百姓善矣。 信者吾信之，有不信者，圣人不分别，吾亦信之，因亦信之，德化百姓信矣。 是故圣人之在天下，不疑於物，则天下物自信； 不私於物，则天下物自公； 不贵於珍，天下自不食； 不奢侈，天下自从俭； 用其实，天下自不伪； 崇其谦，天下自不争。 如此惵惵为天下浑心，百姓皆注其德於耳目，圣人处无心於事，皆孩之也。 出生入死，生之徒十有三，死之徒十有三，民之生动之死地亦十有三。 夫何故？ 以其生生之厚。

The more one strays far from it, the less one knows of it.
Hence, the Sage does not act yet knows,
Does not see yet names,
Does not do yet accomplishes.

The **Dao** uniformly permeates all things,
Yet its knowing lies within oneself.
To seek the **Dao**, one need not step outside the door—
Only reflect upon the mind,
For its essence is one with all things,
Thus one knows all things under Heaven.

If one can further abandon the traces of reflection,
With the mind free from attachments,
Then one need not peer through the window—
Even without outward gaze,
One sees the **Dao** of Heaven.

But if one seeks the **Dao** through calculations,
Through **yin-yang** [阴阳],
Through human affairs,
The farther one strays,
The less one knows.

Hence, the Sage does not act yet knows the nature of all things,
Does not see yet names what Heaven creates,
And remains without doing yet accomplishes all.

In learning, one gains incrementally;
In the **Dao**, one diminishes daily.
Diminish again and again,
Until one reaches **wuwei** [无为],
**Wuwei** yet accomplishes all.

Therefore, those who take all under Heaven,
Always act with **wuwei** [无事],
Yet when they must act,
Their actions are insufficient to take all under Heaven.

For those who learn, daily they strive for increase—
For those who seek the **Dao**, daily they diminish all entanglements.

Now, those who seek learning through increase have two afflictions:
The first is reading, reciting, and copying,
Holding onto many teachings—
This is called **fixation on things** [名着事].

The second is probing into textual meanings,
Exhaustively examining words and logic—
This is called **fixation on principles** [名着理].

These are all cases where the mind has attachments,
Thus they must be diminished.

Those who seek the **Dao** through diminishing also have two afflictions:
The first is severing delusive thoughts,
Seeking stillness outside the mind—
This is called **grasping at nothingness** [名执无].

The second is rejecting all dusty entanglements,
Exclusively guarding the mind—
This is called **grasping at somethingness** [名执有].

These are all cases where the mind clings,
Thus they must be diminished again.

Diminish the mind of learning and the mind of seeking the **Dao**,
Abandon attachments and clinging,
Until one reaches the **Dao** of **wuwei** [无为之道].
**Wuwei** is acting without a fixed mind.
Not without a mind—
It means the mind is devoid of all thoughts,
Called **wuxin** [无心].

Acting without a mind,
Naturally the senses are empty,
Listening and observing freely,
Spontaneously removing poverty and wealth,
Liking and disliking,
The toil of **yunshui** [运水], **banchaishu** [般柴役],
Moving through the world without encumbrance,
Thus **wuwei** yet accomplishes all things.

Hence, those who take and govern all under Heaven with the **Dao**,
Always act with **wuwei** [无事],
Yet when they must act,
Their actions are insufficient to take and govern all under Heaven.

The Sage has no fixed mind,
Taking the hearts of the people as their own.
The virtuous, I treat as virtuous—
The not virtuous, I also treat as virtuous,
Thus **virtue** is accomplished.
The trustworthy, I trust—
The untrustworthy, I also trust,
Thus **virtue** is trustworthy.

The Sage’s presence in all under Heaven,
Is like the sound of **"hunxin"** [浑心],
For the people are all focused on their ears and eyes,
While the Sage nurtures them like children.

The Sage acts with **wuwei** [无为], **wuwei** [无为],
Without fixed intentions in their actions,
Yet responds to affairs with the people’s hearts—
As the *Jiyu* [《击辞》] says:
*"Silent and unmoving, yet responsive—*
*Thus they naturally harmonize with all under Heaven."*

Their **virtue** is revealed through the affairs they encounter.
The virtuous, I treat as virtuous—
If there are the not virtuous,
The Sage does not distinguish,
Yet I also treat them as virtuous,
Thus **virtue** transforms the people into goodness.

The trustworthy, I trust—
If there are the untrustworthy,
The Sage does not distinguish,
Yet I also trust them,
Thus **virtue** transforms the people into trustworthiness.

Therefore, the Sage’s presence in all under Heaven:
If they doubt not the things,
Then all under Heaven’s things become trustworthy;
If they favor not the things,
Then all under Heaven’s things become public;
If they prize not the treasures,
Then all under Heaven will not gluttonously consume;
If they indulge not in excess,
Then all under Heaven will naturally follow frugality;
If they use what is true,
Then all under Heaven will not feign falsity;
If they exalt the humble,
Then all under Heaven will not contend.

Thus, the Sage’s **"hunxin"** [浑心] nurtures all under Heaven,
And the people all focus their **virtue** on their ears and eyes,
While the Sage remains in **wuwei** [无心] toward affairs,
Nurturing them like children.

Birth and death,
Those who live, thirteen in ten,
Those who die, thirteen in ten,
Even the people’s movement from life to death is thirteen in ten.
Why is this so?
Because of the **Dao**’s abundant nurturing of life.

chunks.original_text: 盖闻善摄生者，陆行不遇兕虎，入军不被甲兵。 兕无所投其角，虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃。 夫何故？ 以其无死地。 世人有心出於外，体天地阴阳为法，存想漱咽，吐纳般运之类而求长生者； 又有心入纳也於内，沉空冷静，昏蒙如死者。 老子以十分为率而言之，生之徒十分中有三分，死之徒十分中有三分，死之徒十分中有三分#1，又有民释曰众生。 儒曰：民众萌之谓民。 之缘求养生动之死地，亦十分中有三分。 老子自征问，夫民以衣食养生，何故动之死地？ 以其缘贪生生之过厚故也。 三三类九，皆不取者，缘生之徒心着有，死之徒心着无，民之生心着境，三者心有所着，皆居生死之地。 盖闻善摄无生者#2，离外境，离二边，都无所着，不立於心，见如不见，来如不来，身心一如，故陆行不遇兕虎，入军不被及也甲兵，兕无所投其角，兕如牛，色青，重千斤，一角如鞭，长三尺余。 虎无所措其爪，兵无所容其刃，而使猛兽兵刃不能加害。 夫何故？ 以其心无所着，行住坐卧，心常虚寂。 虚即无相，寂即无生，缘其无生，故无死地。 道生之，德畜之，物形之，势成之，是以万物莫不尊道而贵德。 道之尊，德之贵，莫之爵而常自然。 故道生之畜之，长之育之，成之熟之养之覆之。 生而不有， 为而不恃，长而不宰，是谓玄德。 万物因道而生之，因德而畜孕也之，物之形赖生畜之势而成之，是以万物莫不尊道而贵德也。 且道之尊，德之贵，其理莫之爵位也而常自然矣。 是故万物皆自道生之畜之之育之，成之熟之，养之覆之也。 因道生之而不见其有，因德畜之，养之育之，为而不恃，乃至成之熟之长之而不为主宰，此莫知爵而常自然矣，是谓玄德。 天下有始，以为天下母。 既得其母，以知其子，既知其子，复守其母。 没身不殆。 列子云：夫有形者，生於无形。 故天下有之始者，无也，以无为天下母。 既得其虚无为母，以知其万物皆子； 既知其子，当复守其母。 人能以心合无，如子归母，则没身不殆。 塞其兑，闭其门，终身不勤； 开其兑，济其事，终身不救。 见小曰明，守柔曰强。 用其光，复归其明。 无遗身殃，是谓袭常。 眼耳鼻舌身意谓之六入，因六入而妄生诸缘，而为祸之门也。 老子使人塞其兑兑为窍，闭其六入之门是也。 贪痴既息，则终身不勤劳也。 若开其兑，济其事，纳诸妄缘，则终身不救。 夫六入以心为根，但除其根，则境自灭，故老子曰见小曰明，常无欲，可名於小矣。 守柔曰强。 天下之至柔。 应物随俗，则用其光，内心虚静，是复归其明。 见小曰明，明喻如灯头，光乃外照也。 械之曰无遗其言，失之则为身殃。 不遗其言，是谓袭合也常。 道也 使我介然有知，音智行音衡於大道，惟施是畏。 大道甚夷，而民好音耗径。 朝甚除，田甚芜，仓甚虚，服文采，带利剑，厌饮食，资财有余，是谓道夸，非道也哉。 庄子曰：道无问，问无应。 故大道离言而不可以视听求，不可以思议知，不可以语言及。 应有所施智行言於道者，是可畏也。 故老子曰：使我介作分画也然有智行於大道，惟施是畏。 实告之曰大道甚夷，平也谓无为无事，缘而民人也好径，务一时智识，趣向有为。 又况当时朝廷矜智尚术，甚除其道，田甚荒芜，仓廪甚虚，人竞外华衣服文青与白谓之文采，带权势若利剑，厌饮食骄於味，畜资财图有余，是谓口道言夸道德，理非道也哉。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master of Life Cultivation

It is said that those skilled in nurturing life
walk upon land yet meet no rhinoceros or tiger,
enter battle yet are unharmed by weapons.
The rhinoceros has no place to thrust its horn,
the tiger no place to strike with its claws,
the blade no place to lodge its edge.
Why is this so?
Because they dwell in no place of death.

Some in the world direct their minds outward,
taking Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang as their model,
practicing visualization, gargling, and breath control—
methods like *tuna* and *panrun*—
in their pursuit of longevity.
Others direct their minds inward,
sinking into emptiness and stillness,
becoming dim and lifeless as death itself.

Laozi spoke of ten parts as his standard:
Of those who live, three parts perish;
of those who die, three parts perish#1,
and of the people, some say "all beings."
The Confucian says: "The people are the sprouts of the myriad things."
Yet even among those who seek to nurture life,
three parts perish in the realm of death.
Laozi himself asked: If people nourish life with food and clothing,
why do they perish in the realm of death?
Because they cling excessively to the act of living itself.

Three threes make nine—
all who do not transcend:
those who live cling to being,
those who die cling to non-being,
and the people cling to phenomena.
These three cling to something with their minds,
all dwelling in the realm of life and death.

It is said that those skilled in transcending life
detach from external phenomena,
avoid the two extremes,
and have no attachment at all.
They do not fixate in the mind,
seeing as though not seeing,
coming as though not coming.
Body and mind are as one,
and thus they walk upon land yet meet no rhinoceros or tiger,
enter battle yet are unharmed by weapons.
The rhinoceros—like an ox, blue in color, weighing a thousand *jin*—
has no place to thrust its horn,
the tiger no place to strike with its claws,
the blade no place to lodge its edge.
Thus, fierce beasts and weapons cannot harm them.
Why is this so?
Because their minds are unattached,
and in sitting, standing, moving, or resting,
their minds remain ever empty and still.
Empty means without form,
still means without birth.
Because they are without birth,
they dwell in no place of death.

The Dao gives birth,
virtue nurtures,
things take form,
and circumstances complete them.
Thus, all things do not fail to honor the Dao and revere virtue.
The Dao’s eminence,
virtue’s nobility—
none can bestow these titles,
yet they remain ever natural.

The Dao gives birth and nurtures,
lengthens and matures,
completes and ripens,
nourishes and shelters.
It gives birth yet does not possess,
acts yet does not rely,
lengthens yet does not rule—
this is called the Mysterious Virtue.

All things arise from the Dao and are nurtured by virtue,
their forms shaped by the interplay of giving birth and nurturing,
and thus all things do not fail to honor the Dao and revere virtue.
Moreover, the Dao’s eminence,
virtue’s nobility—
their essence cannot be conferred by rank,
yet they remain ever natural.

Thus, all things are born, nurtured, matured,
completed, ripened, nourished, and sheltered by the Dao.
They arise from the Dao yet are not possessed by it,
are nurtured by virtue yet do not rely upon it,
are lengthened yet are not ruled—
none can bestow these titles,
yet they remain ever natural.
This is called the Mysterious Virtue.

Under Heaven, there is a beginning,
which is the mother of all things.
Having obtained the mother,
one knows her children.
Having known the children,
one returns to guard the mother.
Thus, one’s life will not perish.

Liezi said:
"All that has form arises from the formless."
Thus, the beginning of all things under Heaven is the formless,
and the formless is the mother of all things.
Having obtained the emptiness of the formless as mother,
one knows all things as her children.
Having known the children,
one must return to guard the mother.
If a person can harmonize their mind with the formless,
as a child returns to its mother,
then their life will not perish.

Close the orifices,
shut the gates,
and one will labor no more their whole life.
Open the orifices,
pursue affairs,
and one will never be saved their whole life.

To see small is clarity,
to hold fast to softness is strength.
To use its light,
and return to its clarity—
this leaves no calamity for the body,
and is called "following the constant."

The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind—
these are called the six gates.
Through the six gates, delusive afflictions arise,
and become the door to calamity.
Laozi taught to close the orifices—
the gates are the openings—
and shut the six gates’ doors.
When greed and delusion cease,
one labors no more their whole life.
If one opens the orifices,
pursues affairs,
and admits delusive afflictions,
one will never be saved their whole life.

The six gates take the mind as their root.
If the root is removed,
the phenomena will vanish on their own.
Thus, Laozi said:
"To see small is clarity"—
constantly without desire,
one may be called 'small.'
To hold fast to softness is strength.
The utmost softness under Heaven
responds to things and conforms to customs,
thus using its light.
Within, the mind is empty and still,
and thus returns to its clarity.
'To see small is clarity'—
clarity is like a lamp’s flame,
while light is its outward radiance.
To constrain it is called 'no loss of speech,'
to lose it brings calamity to the body.
Not losing speech is called 'following the constant.'

The Dao makes me distinctly aware—
*zhì* as knowledge, *xíng* as conduct—
and aligns me with the Great Dao,
only to fear its application.
The Great Dao is most level,
yet people prefer narrow paths.
The court is excessively cleared,
fields lie fallow,
granaries are empty,
garments are adorned with embroidery,
belts are girded with sharp blades,
feasts gluttonously indulge,
wealth is hoarded in excess—
this is called boasting of the Dao,
yet it is not the Dao at all.

Zhuangzi said:
"The Dao cannot be questioned,
and questions have no answer."
Thus, the Great Dao transcends speech
and cannot be sought through sight or hearing,
cannot be known through thought or discourse,
cannot be reached through language.
If one applies knowledge, conduct, or speech to the Dao,
then one may truly fear it.

Thus, Laozi said:
"The Dao makes me distinctly aware—
*zhì* as knowledge, *xíng* as conduct—
and aligns me with the Great Dao,
only to fear its application."
Truly, I tell you:
The Great Dao is most level—
plain and without action—
yet people pursue clever shortcuts,
striving for immediate results.
What of the times when courts vaunt cleverness and favor techniques,
when the Dao is neglected,
fields lie fallow,
granaries are empty,
people compete in ornate attire—
garments embroidered with green and white—
and gird themselves with symbols of power like sharp blades,
indulge in gluttonous feasts,
and hoard wealth for surplus—
this is called boasting of the Dao,
yet it is not the Dao at all.

chunks.original_text: 观其世道而施此言，是以可畏。 善建者不拔，善抱者不脱，子孙以祭祀不辗。 修之身，其德乃真； 修之家，其德乃余； 修之乡，其德乃长； 修之国，其德乃丰； 修之天下，其德乃普。 故以身观身，以家观家，以乡观乡，以国观国，以天下观天下。 吾何以知天下之然哉？ 以此。 善建立也德者用之不拔，尽也善抱守也 德者守之不脱，失也如子孙相传，以祭祀不辍。 止也修之於身，其德乃真； 修之於家，一家皆修，其德乃余； 修之乡，一乡皆修，其德乃长； 修之国，一国皆修，其德乃丰； 修之天下，天下皆修，其德乃普。 故以修身之德观身，以修家之德观家，以修乡之德观乡，以修国之德观国，以修天下之德观天下，承承其德，用之不尽，若子孙祭祀相传不止也。 老子曰：吾何以知天下之然哉？ 以此修身之德。 道德真经直解卷之三竟
chunks.translated_text:
Observing the Way of the age and applying these words—
thus it is worthy of fear.

What is well-established cannot be uprooted,
what is well-embraced cannot be abandoned.
Descendants continue through sacrifice without ceasing.

When cultivated in the self, its virtue becomes true;
when cultivated in the family, its virtue overflows;
when cultivated in the neighborhood, its virtue extends;
when cultivated in the state, its virtue flourishes;
when cultivated in the world, its virtue is universal.

Thus, one observes the self through the self,
the family through the family,
the neighborhood through the neighborhood,
the state through the state,
the world through the world.

How do I know the world is thus?
By this.

What is well-established in virtue is used without depletion,
what is well-guarded in virtue is held without loss.
Like descendants transmitting sacrifices without end.

When cultivated in the self, its virtue is true;
when cultivated in the family—if all in the family cultivate—its virtue overflows;
when cultivated in the neighborhood—if all in the neighborhood cultivate—its virtue extends;
when cultivated in the state—if all in the state cultivate—its virtue flourishes;
when cultivated in the world—if all in the world cultivate—its virtue is universal.

Thus, one observes the self through the virtue of self-cultivation,
the family through the virtue of family-cultivation,
the neighborhood through the virtue of neighborhood-cultivation,
the state through the virtue of state-cultivation,
the world through the virtue of world-cultivation,
transmitting virtue endlessly,
using it without depletion,
like descendants passing on sacrifices without ceasing.

Laozi said:
How do I know the world is thus?
By this virtue of self-cultivation.

*The True Scripture of Dao and Virtue: Direct Explanation, Scroll Three, completed.*

chunks.original_text: #1小取大：疑作『以小取大』。 #2所贵此道者，何事也：此句疑衍。 道德真经直解卷之四 本来子邵若愚直解 清河居士张知新校正 含德之厚，比於赤子。 毒虫不螫失亦切，猛兽不据，攫音镢鸟不搏。 骨弱筋柔而握固，未知牝牡之合而绞子垒切作，精之、至也。 终日号音毫而嗌不嘎一迈切，和之至也。 知和曰常，知常曰明。 益生曰祥，心使气曰强。 物壮则老，是谓不道，不道早已音以。 含抱也至德之厚深也者，其行音杏可比 於赤子。 赤子外无物情，内无其心。 无心则物不为对，故毒虫不螫，猛默不据持也，攫鸟不搏手击也。 赤子骨弱筋柔，任手而握物牢固，未知牝牡阴阳也之配合而赤子阴器作长也者，至精之至也。 赤子终日号叫也而嗌咽也不嘎声破也者，至和之至也。 能知无心、至精、至和曰常，知此常乃曰明。 不明常理，百端滋益其生，此曰凶祥。 兆也或用心使气，令体盛实，此曰暂强，乃是衍法而非道也。 夫体盛气强，如物恃壮，物壮则老，是谓不道。 不是道，宜当早已止也。 知者不言，言者不知。 塞其兑，闭其门，挫其锐，解其纷，和其光，同其尘，是谓玄同。 不可得而亲，不可得而疏，不可得而利，不可得而害，不可得而贵，不可得而贱，故为天下贵。 自悟自知者不可言，若殢於言者，则不知。 欲求不可言及之道者，但塞其兑，闭其门，挫其心之锐，解其事之纷。 应事则和其光，处世则同其尘，常应常静，是谓玄同自然。 无憎无爱，所以亲疏自平，利害自除，贵贱自灭，使万物不可得而亲，不可得而疏，不可得而利，不可得而害，不可得而贵，不可得而贱。 诸缘俱息，打断情见，荡然自在，独超万法，故为天下贵。 以正治国，以奇音羁用兵，以无事取天下。 吾何以知其然哉？ 夫天下多忌讳，而民弥贫； 人多利器，国家滋昏，人多伎巧，奇音碁物滋起； 法令滋彰，盗贼多有。 故圣人云：我无为而民自化，我好静而民自正，我无事而民自富，我无欲而民自朴。 其政闷闷，其民淳淳，其政察察，其民缺缺。 祸兮福所倚，福兮祸所伏。 孰知其极？ 其无正耶？
chunks.translated_text:
*The True Scripture of Dao and Virtue: Direct Explanation, Scroll Four*

**#1** *Xiaoqu Da* ["Small Taking Great" — *alternative reading: "Taking the Small to Obtain the Great"*]
**#2** *Suo gui ci Dao zhe, he shi ye* ["What does this Dao/Way value? — *this sentence may be a textual interpolation*"]

The depth of virtue/power is like that of an infant.
Venomous insects do not sting, nor do they bite sharply;
Fierce beasts do not seize it,
Nor do birds of prey snatch—*its grasp is firm and unyielding*.
Its bones are weak, its sinews soft, yet its hold is strong;
It knows not the union of male and female—*yet its essence is supreme*.
It cries all day without its voice breaking—*its harmony is perfect*.
To know harmony is to know constancy,
To know constancy is to know clarity.

To augment life is to bring auspiciousness,
To strain the *qi* by force is to make the body temporarily strong.
When things reach their peak, they grow old—
This is called *not-Dao/Way*,
And *not-Dao/Way* should be abandoned early.

The virtue/power of embracing and nurturing—
When its cultivation is profound,
Its conduct may be likened to that of an infant.
The infant, externally, has no attachments to things,
Internally, has no fixed desires.
Without desires, things cannot sway it—
Thus, venomous insects do not sting,
Fierce beasts do not seize it,
And birds of prey do not snatch its grasp.

The infant’s bones are weak, its sinews soft,
Yet it holds objects firmly with its hands;
It knows not the union of male and female—*yet its vital essence is supreme*.
It cries all day without its voice breaking—*its harmony is perfect*.
To know the infant’s state of no desires,
Its supreme essence, and its perfect harmony—
This is to know constancy,
And knowing constancy is to know clarity.

To fail to grasp this constancy,
To multiply means of augmenting life—
This is called *auspicious calamity*.
Or, to strain the *qi* by force,
To make the body temporarily strong—
This is a contrived method,
Not the true Dao/Way.

When the body is strong and the *qi* is strained,
It is like things relying on their vigor—
Vigor peaks, then decay follows—
This is called *not-Dao/Way*.
Not being the Dao/Way,
It should be abandoned early.

The wise do not speak,
Those who speak are not wise.
Close its *yue* ["cheek/jaw" — *metaphor for excessiveness*],
Shut its door,
Dull its sharpness,
Unravel its entanglements,
Blend its radiance,
Equalize its dust—
This is called *mysterious unity*.

It cannot be drawn near nor kept distant,
Cannot be used for gain nor for harm,
Cannot be exalted nor debased—
Thus, it is held in highest esteem by all under heaven.

Those who awaken to this themselves cannot speak of it;
If they indulge in speech, they do not know it.
To seek the Dao/Way that cannot be spoken,
One must merely close its *yue*,
Shut its door,
Dull the mind’s sharpness,
Unravel the world’s entanglements.
In action, blend its radiance,
In life, equalize its dust—
Constantly responding, yet constantly still—
This is called *mysterious unity of nature*.

Without hatred nor love,
Nearness and distance are naturally balanced,
Gain and harm are naturally removed,
Exaltation and debasement are naturally extinguished—
Thus, all things cannot be drawn near nor kept distant,
Cannot be used for gain nor for harm,
Cannot be exalted nor debased.
All causes cease,
Emotional perceptions are severed,
And it stands effortlessly alone—
Transcending all laws,
Thus it is held in highest esteem by all under heaven.

Govern the state with rectitude,
Employ the *Dao/Way*’s subtlety in warfare—*alternative reading: "strange/uncanny"*,
Gain the world through non-action.
How do I know this to be true?
Under heaven, many taboos exist,

chunks.original_text: 盖治国者，其无正耶？ 今人正复反也为奇，邪也善复为妖，民人也之迷惑，其日固已久矣。 是以圣人大方而不分割，清康而不刿，伤也处直而不申肆，藏光而不炫耀者，皆处於无事也。 治人事天，莫若啬。 音色夫惟啬，是以早复。 早复谓之重真容切积德，重积德则无不克。 无不克则莫知其极，莫知其极，可以有国。 有国之母，可以长久。 是谓深根固柢、长生久视之道。 用智识治人事天下，则失其正，莫若啬。 有而不用曰啬。 夫惟啬，是以早复正也。 早复谓之重积至德，语云：中庸之为德也，其至矣乎？ 民鲜久矣。 重积至德则事无不克。 胜也无不克而非苟且，则莫知其极。 尽也莫知其极，可以有国。 盖正为国之母，有国之母，可以长久，是谓深根固柢，木根柢也乃长生久视之道。 若言治身，当抱其一。 一为形之母，是谓深根固柢，乃长生住世留形久视之道也。 但以一为法，则事无不克矣。 治大国，若烹小鲜。 以道莅天下者，其鬼不神。 非其鬼不神，其神不伤人； 非其神不伤人，圣人亦不伤人。 夫两不相伤，故德交归焉。 治大国若如也烹小鲜鱼也者，谓不可扰也。 扰之则鱼伤，故以用也无为之道莅临也天下者，而民不伤。 至於其鬼人日鬼不为神祟疾疫伤人，非只其鬼不为神祟，其神天曰神亦不为虫蝗水旱伤人。 ，非其神鬼不伤人，缘圣人用无为之道亦不伤人。 夫人神幽显，两不相伤者，故无为则与天地鬼神同德，盖德交合也归焉。 是以无为治天下者，无天怨，无人非，无鬼责。 大国者下流，天下之交，天下之牝，牝常以静胜牡，以静为下。 故大国以下小国，则取小国二，小国以下大国，则取大国。 故或下以取，或下而取。 大国不过欲兼畜人，小国不过欲入事人。 两者各得其所欲，故大者宜为下。 治大国者，宜体天道，下济流行。 夫天下之交，合也观天下之牝，牝，柔静也。 牝常以静胜牡，牡，刚动也。 以静为谦下法。 故大国以用也谦下小国，则取小国附之； 若小国以用也谦下大国，则取大国纳之。 故或用谦下以大取小，或用谦下而小取大＃１。 大国不过欲兼畜养也人，是乐天者也。 小国不过欲入事人，是畏天者也。 孟子曰：乐天者保天下，畏天者保其国。 两者各得其所欲，故居大者不可恃强，宜为下之也。 道者，万物之奥也，善人之宝，不善人之所保。 美言可以市，尊行音杏可以加於人。 人之不善，何弃之有？ 故立天子，置三公，虽有拱璧以先驷马，不如坐进此道。 古之所以贵此道，何也？ 不曰音越求以得，有罪以免耶？ 故为天下贵。 道者，乃万物之奥也。 善道人贵道之若宝，不善道人恃德之所保身，是故尊道为美言，从之可以如市，以德为尊行，可以加於人。 夫人不善道德者，又何弃之有也？ 故如尧让许 由，立为天子，楚置庄周为三公，招贤之聘，虽有拱璧圭璧也，玉为之。 以先前也驷乘之马，公卿之车如此之荣不受而隐去，是不如坐进此道也。 然古之所以贵此道者，何事也？ 所贵此道者，何事也＃２？ 所贵者，其心无欲。 视荣华如尘垢，而不曰求其以得者，有着境妄念之罪以免耶？ 故为天下贵。 为无为，事无事，味无味。 大小多少，报怨以德。 圣人为而无为者，是处事於无事也，此恬惔之德，其味无味。
chunks.translated_text:
「Indeed, those who govern the realm—do they lack rectitude?
Nowadays, the upright are deemed strange, while the perverse are praised as virtuous;
the people are long ensnared in confusion.
Thus, the Sage acts broadly without division,
pure and serene without harshness,
punishes wrongs directly yet does not indulge in retaliation,
and conceals brilliance without ostentation—
all these stem from the state of non-action.

In managing both human affairs and the Dao of Heaven,
nothing surpasses frugality.
Frugality is the essence of *early-complex*—
thus, *early-complex* is born.
*Early-complex* is called the profound embodiment of virtue and the accumulation of *power*—
accumulating *power* ensures nothing is unconquered.
If nothing is unconquered,
yet none know its limit,
then one can establish a state.
A state with such foundation
can endure long.
This is the Dao of deep-rooted stability,
long life and enduring vision.

If one governs with wisdom and discernment,
one loses the proper way—
nothing surpasses frugality.
To possess yet not use is called frugality.
Frugality is the origin of *early-complex* and rectitude—
thus, *early-complex* is born.
*Early-complex* is called the accumulation of supreme virtue.
As the saying goes:
*"Moderation (中庸), as a virtue, is it not supreme?"*
The people have long been few in virtue.
Accumulating supreme virtue ensures no task is unconquered.
To conquer all without haste,
yet none know its limit,
then one can establish a state.
Rectitude is the foundation of a state;
a state with such foundation
can endure long—
this is the Dao of deep-rooted stability,
the roots and foundation of wood,
which brings long life and enduring vision.

As for governing one’s own person,
one must embrace unity.
Unity is the origin of form—
this is the Dao of deep-rooted stability,
long life, abiding in the world,
preserving form, and enduring vision.
But if one takes unity as the law,
then no task is unconquered.

To govern a great state,
one must treat it as if boiling a small fish—
*[i.e., with gentle, non-intrusive care]*.
Those who govern the world with the Dao of non-action
have no fearsome ghosts.
Not that their ghosts are not fearsome,
but that their fearsome nature does not harm people;
not that their fearsome nature does not harm people,
but that the Sage also does not harm people.
When both do not harm each other,
then virtue returns in harmony.
To govern a great state as if boiling a small fish
means one must not disturb it.
Disturbing it harms the fish,
so those who govern with the Dao of non-action
do not harm the people.
As for ghosts and spirits harming people—
not only do the ghosts not harm them,
but the Heavenly spirits also do not bring pestilence, famine, or drought to harm them.
When spirits and ghosts do not harm people,
it is because the Sage governs with the Dao of non-action
and thus does not harm people either.
For when human and spiritual realms—
both hidden and manifest—
do not harm each other,
then non-action aligns with the virtue of Heaven and Earth,
ghosts and spirits—
virtue converges and returns in harmony.

Thus, those who govern the world with non-action
face no Heavenly resentment,
no human criticism,
no ghostly reproach.
A great state is the confluence of all lands,
the gathering of the world,
the receptive feminine principle of the world.
The feminine principle is ever victorious over the masculine through stillness,
and stillness is the yielding, receptive way.
Thus, a great state yields to small states,
and the small states submit to it;
a small state yields to great states,
and the great states embrace it.
Hence, sometimes yielding brings conquest,
sometimes yielding brings submission.
A great state seeks only to nurture and shelter its people—
this is the joy of Heaven.
A small state seeks only to serve and submit to others—
this is the fear of Heaven.
Mencius said:
*"Those who take joy in Heaven preserve the world,
those who fear Heaven preserve their own state."*
Both attain their desires—
thus, those in great states must not rely on strength,
but rather on yielding.

The Dao is the hidden mystery of all things,
the treasure of the virtuous,
and the refuge of the unvirtuous.
Fine words can be sold like goods in the market,
and noble deeds can be bestowed like the *xing* [杏] fruit.
If people are unvirtuous,
why would one abandon them?
Thus, when establishing a Son of Heaven,
and appointing the Three Exalted Ministers,
even if one is offered a jade tablet with a bow
or four horses in advance,
it is not as valuable as simply receiving this Dao.
Why did the ancients hold this Dao in such esteem?
Was it not because they sought it to obtain,
or pardoned crimes to escape?
Thus, it is held in esteem by all under Heaven.
The Dao is the hidden mystery of all things.
The virtuous cherish the Dao as a treasure,
while the unvirtuous rely on virtue as their refuge.
Thus, honoring the Dao as fine words,
following it can be as effortless as selling in the market;
virtue as noble deeds,
can be bestowed upon people.
If people do not embrace virtue and the Dao,
why would one abandon them?
Thus, like Yao yielding the throne to Xu You,
and setting him as Son of Heaven,
or Chu appointing Zhuang Zhou as Three Exalted Minister,
though invited with jade tablets and noble gifts,
though given carriages of ministers and the honor of horses,
they declined and withdrew—
this was not as valuable as simply receiving this Dao.

But why did the ancients esteem this Dao?
What was the reason they esteemed this Dao?
The reason they esteemed it
was that the heart harbors no desires.
They viewed honor and splendor as dust and filth,
and did not say,
*"I seek it to obtain,"*
or *"I cling to it to escape crime."*
Thus, it is held in esteem by all under Heaven.

To act without acting,
to do without doing,
to savor without savoring—
great or small, many or few,
repaying resentment with virtue.
The Sage acts without acting,
dwelling in the realm of doing nothing—
this is the virtue of serenity and ease,
its flavor without savoring.»

chunks.original_text: 应大与小，言其形多与少，言其数尘境妄缘，能为怨对者，以无心为事，故云报怨以德。 图难於其易，为大於其细。 天下之难事必作於易，天下之大事必作於细，故圣人终不为大，故能成其大。 夫人欲图难者，又先於其易。 欲为大者，必先於其细。 小也天下之难事必作为也於易，天下之大事必作为也於细，是故圣人而无所作，终不为大，故能成其大。 夫轻诺必寡信，多易必多难，是以圣人由难之，故终无难矣。 夫轻诺许从，后必寡信。 缘於多易，后必多难。 是以圣人应世而母必由难之，故至终无难矣。 其安易持，其未兆易谋，其脆易泮，其 微易散。 为之於未有，治之於未乱。 合抱之木，生於毫末； 九层之台，起於累土； 千里之行，始於足下。 为者败之，执者失之。 是以圣人无为故无败，无执故无失。 故民之从事，常於几成而败之，慎终如始，则无败事矣。 是以圣人欲不欲，不贵难得之货； 学不学，以复众人之所过，以辅万物之自然而不敢为。 其安易保持於危，其未兆易谋於已成，其冰脆薄则易泮冰散也，盖其微者 易散也。 凡事为之於未有之际，治之於未乱之时。 夫合抱之木由生於毫末，九层之台起於累土，千里之行始於足下，事皆从微而至大，不可不慎也。 凡有为者，故有败之应； 有所执者，故有失之。 是以圣人处事於无为，故无败，无执故无失。 是故民人也之从有为之事者，常於几成而败之。 几者，心动之微也。 心未动以前，心处於无而不名，几动则显露，亦不名几。 几者，心始离无入有，在有之微，乃欲之初，事之始也。 若能慎事至终如事之始，则无败事矣。 是以圣人欲不欲者，慎心动之微。 不贵难得之货者，慎事动之微。 故知圣人之学，不用几识为学，以复众人之所过也，以辅顺也万物之自然而不敢为。 古之善为道者，非以明民，将以愚之。 民之难治，以其智多。 故以智治国，国之贼； 不以智治国，国之福。 知此两者亦楷式。 常知楷式，是谓玄德。 玄德深矣远矣，与物反矣，然后乃至大顺。 古之善为道治天下者，非不也以用也智见明民，用智治世，是将以愚民之也。 民之难治者，以其智多，故以智治国，国之贼； 不以智治国，国之福。 知此两者亦楷模也式。 常知楷式，是谓玄德。 玄德之理深矣远矣，谓与物事也反矣。 不以智识明民，然后乃至大顺天下俱顺。 江海所以能为百谷王者，以其善下之也，故能为百谷王。 是以圣人欲上人，以其言下之； 欲先人，以其身后之。
